bug.short_desc: [ErrorHandling] JFace SafeRunnable should use new error handling

long_desc.thetext: Currently, SafeRunnable opens a modal dialog. This is problematic because of the side-effects of spinning the event loop (see e.g. bug 154571), and because sometimes many dialogs are displayed after another, or closing one dialog leads to another. SafeRunnable should use the new error handling facility, and the error handling facility should collect similar errors together to present them in one dialog instead of in many.
Note that the current error handling implemented by SafeRunnable is not configurable (e.g. for RCP applications) - by using the new error handling facility, I would expect this to change.
We cannot do this without an API change. We will want to fix the specific cases in anyways so I am not sure if we want to plug-in the status handling this late in the game.

As the one filing this bug originally, I am strongly in favour of fixing this for 3.3 even if we need API to do it. The error reporting in SafeRunnable can lead to really bad behaviour (e.g., see bug 148005, bug 171605, bug 163077).
ping

Created an attachment (id=62278) patch
This patch adds API. Unfortunately, we missed this bug before the API freeze.
While writing this, we noticed that StatusManager.getManager() is spec'd to return null in some cases. Can this please be changed? (We need an API change approval for that as well, but it's not going to break any clients.)
Szymon please review and commandt on this patch

Created an attachment (id=62476) Fixed patch
API looks good
I made some changes in Policy#getDummyStatusManager - style can be OR combined, so we can't use 'switch' - the dialog icon now depends on the status severity
I modified 'since' tag in get/setStatusManager methods from 3.1 to 3.3
Javadoc for getStatusManager looked bad. I fixed it.
Javadoc for AbstractStatusManager had to be fixed. I did it.

And question...
Is the abstract class AbstractStatusManager better than the interface IStatusManager?
I think that we can do it similar to logging with ILogger.
Created an attachment (id=62479) Fixed patch with fix from comment no 9

Created an attachment (id=62486) Alternative solution patch
It looks like more what we have for the logging.
(In reply to comment #11) I will change this when we decide which API to choose.

Looking at the alternative solution I think we want to avoid using an interface as it gives us no room to grow the API - I think it is better as an abstract class.
handle API still needs improving but it is otherwise OK for me.

(In reply to comment #14) > AbstractStatusManager#handle needs some better javadoc as it is unclear if the > style bit is additive or not. Szymon you said the case statement wouldn't work > for the additive case - does your patch need to be updated to reflect that.
Yes
> And we still haven't heard why we need the workbench running to use the status > handling..... >
I'm using handlers defined in the extensions during handling. This is the reason.
What I can do, is to log errors and all statuses unless workbench is running.
(In reply to comment #15) > > handle API still needs improving but it is otherwise OK for me. >
What kind of improvement?

(In reply to comment #16)
Sorry, I made a mistake in the comment. My patch reflects this additive style bit :-)

(In reply to comment #16) > I'm using handlers defined in the extensions during handling. This is the > reason. > > What I can do, is to log errors and all statuses unless workbench is running.
Yes, you should do that so that clients don't have to deal with the null case.

This looks like it's going to address the general issue in https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=103295.
Is this new error handling stuff already in HEAD? (If not, when's the planned push?)
I'd also like to check on whether this bug is tracking the removal of other Eclipse code that pops up message dialogs within ISafeRunnable implementations...this is a general problem that we need to solve for our RCP application.

(In reply to comment #19) > Is this new error handling stuff already in HEAD? (If not, when's the planned > push?)
I don't think it is in HEAD yet - Szymon?
> I'd also like to check on whether this bug is tracking the removal of other > Eclipse code that pops up message dialogs within ISafeRunnable > implementations...this is a general problem that we need to solve for our RCP > application.
Could you please file a new bug for this, ideally with pointers to code that needs to be fixed? Thanks.
*** Bug 103295 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Progressive bar keeps going if use report tag to display parameter.[0603]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Progressive bar keeps going in IE6 when use birt:report to display report containing parameter.
Build number: 2.2.0.v20061216
Steps to reproduce: 1. New a BIRT Web Project. 2. New a jsp file based on BIRT template. 3. Input content in body as (test.rptdesign is birt sample report containing a normal report parameter): <birt:report id="0" reportDesign="test.rptdesign" height="500" width="500"> </birt:report> 4. Run the jsp file.
Expected result: After input parameter value and click OK, the report content displays.
Actual result: After input parameter value and click OK, the report content does display. But in IE the progressive bar keeps going, and if you select the url, you will found the url kept refreshing. This issue doesn't exist in Firefox1.5.
Due to IE settings issue, Can't reproduce it widely.

bug.short_desc: Allow plug-ins to be installed by following a link

long_desc.thetext:
To allow quicker and easier installation of plug-ins, it would be nice if a user could just follow a link in a browser saying "Install this plug-in" - this link would cause Eclipse to start and allow the user to select the plug-in(s) to install (somewhat like when a Firefox add-on is installed).
This could be implemented by specifying a custom MIME type for a site.xml file, which Eclipse could be registered as a handler for.

New jsp file viewer.jsp based on (html,BIRT tag) template, input content like: <birt:viewer id="0" title="contextRoot" contextRoot="wtp2" reportDesign="birt_tag_sample.rptdesign"> </birt:viewer>. bug.short_desc: ScaledGraphics does not support SWT Path

long_desc.thetext: The scaled graphics does not have support to draw or fill paths. Now that SWT supports scaling and paths, we should be able to just scale the GC, draw the path, and put the GC back to its original state.

Created an attachment (id=55811) opps.. here is the actual patch
This is the patch

ScaledGraphics is intended to provide a fake version of scaling which: 1) Does not scale line widths with zoom 2) Does not require advanced graphics
Obviously the second restriction can be relaxed in some cases, but I don't see any way of scaling drawPath() without scaling the line width, so the patch wouldn't work.
This is a duplicate of bug 103717. Also, bug 132361 is a duplicate of bug 103717, and it mentions another use case (thumbnail).

What if we translated the points on the path to their new scaled location?
that is a path that goes from (0,0)-(10,10)-(50,50)-(0,0) scaled by 2 would give (0,0)-(20,20)-(100,100)-(0,0)
Do you think this would work?

> Hello, > > please could you include this fix in the next builds ? >
We'd still be missing support for fillPath, clipPath, which are possible using the same code, if refactored. Can you append the patch to handle all API using Paths?
Of course, clipRegion, setBackground/ForegroundPattern, rotate etc still don't work for ScaledGraphics.

Created an attachment (id=82084) path zooming patch
includes:
- drawPath - fillPath - setClip(Path) - translat(float,float)
Created an attachment (id=82085) Example for patrh zooming

Hello,
could you let me know whether you plan to commit this fix and when ? Also, will it be fixed in a maintenance release of Europa ?
This is an annoying bug....

(In reply to comment #9) > could you let me know whether you plan to commit this fix and when ? Also, will > it be fixed in a maintenance release of Europa ?
We will look at the patch for Ganymede (GEF 3.4)

bug.short_desc: Add ability to get bugzilla web path from bug form

long_desc.thetext:
Rob, what do you think about the ability to get the web path from a bug report. I often have a task (bug) in mylar and I want to send the link to someone not using mylar. It would be nice to right click on the bug ID field and have an option like "copy as web link". This would copy the web link to the clipboard
https://server/show_bug?id=BUG_ID.
I don't know if this is generic for all bugzilla installations or only bugs.eclipse.org.

We have something along these lines from within the task list. If you select a task and copy (Ctrl+c) from the popup menu this will copy the task name and hyperlink to the clipboard for easy pasting. But sometimes it is inconvenient to have to go back to the tasklist from the editor to get this info into the clipbard. So I agree that we need this capability from within the task editor itself.
We can't use copy since that would overload the action in the editor popup menu. Willian and Eugene have been suggesting (see bug#161740) that selection of bug#<num> enable an action to add the selected bug to the tasklist. I think it makes sences to add the 'copy web link' action here as well. Would this work for you Ian?
Rob, for this request it probably makes sense to add "Copy Details" action into the task editor popup menu but don't map it to Ctrl-C.

(In reply to comment #2) > Rob, for this request it probably makes sense to add "Copy Details" action into > the task editor popup menu but don't map it to Ctrl-C. >
I think what Ian wants is more a "Copy URL" option.
I like the "copy as web link" when the bug# is selected makes sense. It doesn't have to be on ctrl-c.

From his description it seems like copy details would be as fine. It would copy following format to the clipboard:
[id] [summary] [url]
That can be quite convenient when sending in email...

So Ian: are you asking for more than Copy Details provides? Our experiences are that while [id] [summary] are extra, they are useful because the person you are sending to will see what they are clicking before they click it.

Not more than copy details. I wasn't really asking for the details, but I think they are a good idea. I was hoping for something on the Bugzilla form (not the task list) because if I have the bug report open, then I don't want to try and find it again in my task list.
What about just adding "copy details" to the context menu on the bugzilla form?

Done, the action is now on the editor as well, and I added this to the Tips & Tricks: http://www.eclipse.org/mylar/tips.php
Note that if you want just the URL you can use the Open with Browser action and get it from the address bar.
Created an attachment (id=55893) mylar/context/zip

Thanks...
Actually I used the address bar before, but for some reason mozilla on my linux box has been un-installed, so I don't have a browser anymore :(
- ian
By the way, Mik, Ctrl-c accelerator look somehow odd. Can you please change it to Ctrl-C ?
That's on the table, but requires additional changes because big-C currently does not work (perhaps because it is reserved for retargetable actions, which this one should be).

bug.short_desc: Frameborder doesn't work in birt:report tag..[0603]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Frameborder doesn't work in birt:report tag.
Build number:2.2.0.v20061216
Steps to reproduce: 1. New a BIRT Web Project. 2. New a jsp file based on BIRT template and input content in body as below: <birt:report id="1" reportDesign="birt_tag_sample.rptdesign" contextRoot="wtp_jsp_tags" frameborder="1"> </birt:report> <birt:report id="1" reportDesign="birt_tag_sample.rptdesign" contextRoot="wtp_jsp_tags" frameborder="yes"> </birt:report> 3. Run the wtp project in server and preview the jsp file.
Expected result: a. Border style shows up. b. If report tag doesn't support frameborder, the property support should be removed from this tag and related specification.
Actual result: No effect and no errors to say that frameborder isn't supported.
Error log:N/A
"frameborder" attribute only takes effect on IFrame element. When use DIV as report container, it is useless. User can use "forceIFrame" attrubte to force using IFrame.
I think forceIFrame attribute can fix this issue, and we can write down in the spec that frameborder attribute is based on foreIFrame attribute. So reopen it for fix.
It is better that changing forceIFrame attribute default value from false to true.
Verify in build 2.2.0.v20061220

bug.short_desc: Support the new SWT Line Attributes

long_desc.thetext:
The new SWT (3.3 M4) now supports a Line Attribute to set things like fractional line width and line style offsets. I think GEF's SWT Graphics (and scaled graphics) should support setting this.
Any thoughts?

based on a quick look at the code, it seems like this feature could be made available by fairly small modifications to SWTGraphics. the "currentstate" and "appliedstate" variables would need to accept a float line width. the various "checkXXX" methods would need to call "gc.setLineAttributes" to use the new API.
the most visible change is that the "Graphics" abstract class would need a "setLineWidth(float)" method in addition to the existing "setLineWidth(int)".
am i missing something?
if this is the case, i'd be happy to make the changes and submit a patch.
regards,
al

The LineAttribute class has a few other options such as join and line style. I don't know if these are the same as what was previously available in SWT or if SWT has introduced new options (that are only available through the new line attribute API). If the only new features are fractional line widths then I think you are correct.
Does anyone else know? Also, if we change SWTGraphics we may have to updated ScaledGraphics too.

i didn't look at the other options in detail, because i'm primarily interested in fractional line widths. similar extensions to Graphics can probably be applied in those cases as well.
in addition to SWTGraphics, all subclasses of Graphics, including ScaledGraphics would have to implement "setLineWidth(float)" but all changes seem likely to be straightforward. Right now, my java search (over GEF, BIRT, VE, DTP, WTP, Zest) reveals only 4 sub-classes of Graphics: SWTGraphics, ScaledGraphics, PrinterGraphics and XYScaledGraphics. only the last one is not part of GEF/draw2d (and it appears that Ian may be responsible for that :-). so it seems that adding the extra methods to Graphics should not impact too much code.
if adding methods to Graphics is not acceptable, perhaps an extension interface "IGraphicsExtn" may be implemented by SWTGraphics?
but something really should be done. IMO fractional line widths is too important a feature of SWT to leave out of GEF/draw2d. and it'd be nice to get done in time for Europa.
regards,
al

Adding a new method to Graphics is fine and it's one of the reasons Graphics is not an interface. If we were to add setLineWidth(float), we could even have a reasonable default implementation that called the int version.
But, I'm not sure that's the right addition. GC has setLineAttributes, not setLineWidth(float). So, it would seem that we should go with the same approach. I think LineAttributes implies advanced graphics, so look at how Patterns are implemented in SWTGraphics. Also, I'm assuming LineAttributes pre-empts all previously set attributes, perhaps they are mutually exclusive. But what happens if I set the LineAttributes, then go back and set the lineDash only? Is the line width still factional? In other words, what is the actual SWT behavior so that we can maintain those expectations?
Check out restoreState and reconcileHints. Those methods would have to be updated to handle when LineAttributes are present.

Randy, Do you think it is worthy asking the SWT team why they implemented it this way? At first I would have gone with the simple approach and just added setLineWidth(float), but I'm sure there is good reason they didn't do this. (Maybe setLineAttribute was less intrusive on the existing API). I think we should probably follow the same pattern as SWT, assuming the SWT team is happy with this approach.

Created an attachment (id=56619) Modified SWT snippet
comment out various lines to see the effect of "setLineXXX" calls

i did a few quick tests (i'm attaching the snippet). it appears that a) calling setLineAttributes does indeed put the gc into advanced graphics mode. b) calls to "setLineWidth", "setLineCap" and "setLineStyle" appear to interoperate with "setLineAttributes". egs. the last call to setLineCap will change the line cap without resetting line width.
so actual SWT behavior seems pretty intuitive.
i'm fine with randy's suggestion. i.e. a single "setLineAttributes" method. unless anyone has any other suggestions, i'll try to do a first run through on the changes in the next day or so. i'll be testing against my own apps initially.

> interoperate with "setLineAttributes". egs. the last call to setLineCap will > change the line cap without resetting line width.
How annoying. This means it actually behaves like individual properties, but they've created API that takes a "Struct". So in order to restore state, we need to restore the LineAttributes, and then also restore any settings which were applied after the line attributes, but not the ones before. All of our "enums" would need to add one value for "unset".
That doesn't sound ideal. How about if the existing methods (e.g. setLineDash, setLineCap, etc.) apply themselves to (lazily-created copies of) the LineAttributes when one exists. That way, if LineAttributes exists, it completely replaces the other stored values.
Can I call setLA(null) on GC?

> That doesn't sound ideal. How about if the existing methods (e.g. setLineDash, setLineCap, etc.) > apply themselves to (lazily-created copies of) the LineAttributes when one exists. That way, > if LineAttributes exists, it completely replaces the other stored values.
if i understand you correctly, all the existing attribute code (including "checkXXX") has two paths. one when LA is null which is identical to what happens currently. and another when LA is non-null in which case LA attributes are modified? so State and LazyState remain the same, except for the addition of an LA variable. that may be the simplest solution.
> Can I call setLA(null) on GC? nope. that's an error.

ok. i've made the changes to Graphics and SWTGraphics and tested against my existing app (i.e. didn't use the LineAttribute feature as yet). everything works as before.
now, i want to do the same thing, but with fractional line widths. here i'm running into a new issue.
i'm using various subclasses of Shape for the actual painting. unfortunately, Shape keeps it's own internal lineWidth which is currently an int. changing this to a float and adding a new setLineWidth(float) is fairly straightforward (may also have to deprecate the int method?), and so is changing the call to gc.setLineWidth to use gc.setLineAttributes. but the linewidth is also used for calculating the bounding rectangle (which has integer only coordinates) in outlineShape as well as getBounds. i can take a shot at changing the calculations for all the existing shapes, but i'm not a low-level graphics expert.
any advice?
thx.

I had another question first. Is LineAttributes mutable? If it is, we can't hold onto the line attributes the user passed us (because the user may change it). If it isn't, we can't modify it during subsequent calls to setLineDash(), etc. So either case suggests that holding onto the client's passed LineAttributes instance is not the right thing to do. In which case, maybe we should support the LineAttributes for the official API, but the States should just hold onto the raw attributes, with some kind of special handling for int/float representation of line width.
If someone is patching graphics, note that SWTGraphics is currently broken for setLineDash(int[]). The API specifies that this value may not get stored and restored. As with line width, there are two possible values that are mutually exclusive. The SWT defined enums, and the user's custom value.
As far as improving the Shapes hierarchy, open a separate bug. The deciding factors would be binary compatibility and/or memory concerns.

(In reply to comment #11) > I had another question first. Is LineAttributes mutable? If it is, we can't hold
LineAttributes is mutable. i hadn't thought about that aspect. are you sure it's not just better to have a "setLineWidth(float)" and be done with it (i.e. not even try to support LineAttribute directly)
> If someone is patching graphics, note that SWTGraphics is currently broken for > setLineDash(int[]). The API specifies that this value may not get stored and > restored. As with line width, there are two possible values that are mutually > exclusive. The SWT defined enums, and the user's custom value.
are you suggesting that this be fixed? or that it's not fixable? i'd be willing to take a look at it.
> As far as improving the Shapes hierarchy, open a separate bug. The deciding > factors would be binary compatibility and/or memory concerns.
AFAICT, without this fix, the change to SWTGraphics does nothing for me, i.e. i cannot use fractional width lines. i'd have to stop using the Shape hierarchy altogether.

Created an attachment (id=57338) Fixes to Graphics and Shape hieararchies
The submitted patch fixes the Graphics hiearchies to allow line attributes.
I've also included a very simple-minded fix to the Shape hierarchies to permit fractional line widths. assuming that (int)(float)x = x, this patch should be backward compatible with integer linewidths. not entirely sure that it's the best solution for fractional linewidths.
i haven't done a lot of testing. but my app works correctly with these patches. feedback is welcome.

Created an attachment (id=72794) patch for eclipse 3.3
the old patch was no longer applying cleanly to recent draw2d versions. these are the same changes 'rebased' to draw2d HEAD as of jun 20 '07.
feedback / suggestions for improvement are welcome.
I will review the patch.

bug.short_desc: Default width for birt:report tag is different for html and pdf.[0603]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Default width for birt:report tag is different for html and pdf.[0603]
Build number:2.2.0.v20061216
Steps to reproduce: 1. New a jsp file based on birt template. 2. Input inside body: <birt:report id="1" contextRoot= "wtp_jsp_tags" reportDesign="birt_tag_sample.rptdesign" height="600" scrolling="yes"> </birt:report> <birt:report id="2" contextRoot= "wtp_jsp_tags" reportDesign="birt_tag_sample.rptdesign" format="pdf" height="600" scrolling="yes"> </birt:report> 3. Preview the jsp file
Expected result: with predefined height, html and pdf should use same default width.
Actual result: html's width is larger than pdf.

It depends on web browser behavior.The first tag uses "DIV" as report container and the other one uses "IFrame".If don't set width for them, they have the different appearance. So user had better specify width attribute for "IFrame".
Close it. Use iframe as container by default intead of div, so this issue doesn't exist now.

bug.short_desc: CDO and SessionInvalidationListener

long_desc.thetext:
Stephen:
I see the same thing (or something very similar). Specifically, in AbstractDataRequest.receiveObject(...), I see where the new objects are added in receiveReferences(...), but I see no place where a removed object gets removed.
In my specific use case I am moving an object from a non-containment reference of one object to another. When the object is moved from one list to the other, the object apears to be in both lists.
Fixed by unsetting all references of objects to be reloaded prior to setting the new reference values.
Committed to CVS
Fixed

bug.short_desc: [ecore diagram] enable delete from diagram

long_desc.thetext:
In many meta-models you will end up with for example a class called NamedElement. Nearly every element in the diagram has a generalisation to that element which makes it harder to understand the diagram.
It would be nice to have an option to remove a specific class from the diagram only.

I can see two possible solutions for this problem: 1. Make Ecore diagram non-synchronized 2. Generate "show/hide" actions.
For now you can create new diagram and add corresponding aspect of your meta-model as a shortcuts to this new diagram.

I'd prefer the second solution.
I opened a more general request at #168324
Thanks for the workaround
Looks like this request will be covered by fixing the one describing hide/show actions.

bug.short_desc: Ctrl+Space in display view doesn't work after detaching the view

long_desc.thetext:
I'm getting this behavior in the display view in version 3.2.1. I detached the display view. When this view was detached not only I Ctrl+Space content assist doesn't work, but also Ctrl+U doesn't work for executing the marked lines (though for executing the menu button does work, just Ctrl+U is ignored).
When I re-attached the view to the main eclipse window, Ctrl+U started working again, but the content assist didn't.
Not planned for 3.3

bug.short_desc: Add a filter for any kind of element to the diagram actions

long_desc.thetext:
First of all, I don't know if I have chosen the right component. So please move, if I haven't...
Is would be useful to have a option to filter elements. I'd like to hide one ore more model elements from a diagram. The implementation should be quite similar tor "Delete from diagram", right? When executing this action a tree could show up where the elements to hide/show could be selected. The tree could be retrieved from the underlying model. Maybe it would be useful, too, to have a filter which hides any element from the diagram which is of a certain type.
AFAIK, runtime support this option so, we can generate corresponding action based on some properties in .gmfgen model. Should we redirect this request to the generation?
Duplicate of request #145759?

What VM are you using?

$java -version
java version "1.5.0_09" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_09-b01) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_09-b01, mixed mode, sharing)
Przemyslaw, is it possible that JDK 1.5.0_09 had bug 168043? I can confirm that bug 168043 does not happen in 1.5.0_08. Does the example code that bug report fail for you on the JDK you are running?
Look bad ... I can confirm that the code in bug 168043 works for 1.5.0_10. It's possible that it was broken for 1.5.0_09 then fixed for 1.5.0_10 then broken again for 1.6 (but this is very unlikely).

bug.short_desc: [1.5][compiler] AbstractMethodError on interface method

long_desc.thetext: The bug has been introduced between 3.3M3 and 3.3M4.
v_722 compiles it fine and v_723 fails. This narrows down when the problem was introduced.
Will investigate.
Released InnerEmulationTest#133 and 134 (inactive) in HEAD. Considering test133 test case, we miss a bridge method in X$Y.class, which was properly generated until v_723.
Released InnerEmulationTest#133 and 134 (active) in R3_2_maintenance.

This is a regression introduced by the fix for bug 162073. In fact, we must delay the elimination from the inherited methods of the interface methods that are implemented, so as to enable the bridge methods generation. The more recent fix for bug 161541 eliminates duplicates later in the process (to fulfill other needs), which happens to fix bug 162073 as well, modulo a few changes in error messages. I will revert the change for bug 162073 and clarify the semantics of isInterfaceMethodImplemented, fix the error messages and see where we get.

Erratum: bug 162073 is *not* fixed if I remove the change. Need to be more cautious here. There is a tension between the needs of method verification (namely catch truly incompatible return types) and of bridge methods generation (need a bridge method if the return type is compatible but different).

Created an attachment (id=56701) Fix plus test cases activation
This fix does the following: - it reverts to v_722 for the construction of the inheritedMethods collection (in the method verifier); - while verifying the inherited methods in MethodVerifier15#checkInheritedMethods, it suppresses overriden methods from implemented/inherited interfaces before delegating the ultimate checks to MethodVerifier#checkInheritedMethods.
Currently under test.

Created an attachment (id=56796) Fix + test cases - improved
This fix builds upon the ideas of the first one, and especially gets rid of the initial fix for bug 162073, but: - eliminates overridden methods later, and only does so for a specific check (does not keep the results for further use); - uses a better criterion to eliminate the overridden methods.
Released for 3.3 M5.

Created an attachment (id=56896) Smaller fix only addresses regression
Reopening bug 162073, and simply reverting its changes.
Verified for 3.3 M5 using warm-up build I20070205-0009
*** Bug 173477 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Works fine again in 3.3 M5. Thank you very much!
*** Bug 176528 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: auto-update serialVersionUID when saving

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1. no 2. steps 3. at all
More information: It would make quite a lot sense if eclipse would auto-update a class' serialVersionUID when saving if the class' semantics has changed.
This can potentially break existing serialized instances of the class which were serialized with the old serialVersionUID. Move to JDT/UI.
I don't thing it's a good idea to make that on save. It's a.) very expensive to do, and better be user controlled.
You are probably right, but it should be at least a warning (like unused imports etc.).

Only the developper can know when a change to the class leads to incompatibility. There's no way around it: serialVersionUID should be added when creating a class andhas to be maintained by the developper.

bug.short_desc: [activity] link repository fields to task fields

long_desc.thetext: it would be helpful if personal fields could be linked to central repository fields too. e.g the trac plugin http://trac-hacks.org/wiki/TimingAndEstimationPlugin has effort fields, the milestone attached to a trac ticket gives the date when it should be fixed.

Linking custom fields sounds like a very useful feature indeed. It would also be nice to synchronize the active time recorded by Mylar.
Would you be interested in providing a patch?
This is related to bug 173880, and it is likely that we will eventually want this as API.
Tentatively scheduling for 3.0.

bug.short_desc: Product export does not set the correct permissions for the copied JRE

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061214-1445
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create a Plugin/RCP project 2. Create a .product configuration 3. Export this configuration with a bundled jre 4. Launch the exported product 5. It fails with a jvm error
After setting the executable-permission on the java binary everythings works fine
PDE seems to simply copy the files. Under Windows this will work. But under Unixoid systems the executable permissions must be set. The problem is: How is that possible with java 1.5? 1.6 seems to provide the necessary methods. Or has eclipse something to offer?
More information:
Note that when using root.permissions properties along with the root.folder properties, you should refer to the destination folder since the chmods happen after the copy.

I suppose I should also answer Dominik's question: The export is actually done by generating and running ant scripts. So the permissions are set using ant's chmod. (Assuming of course that the correct properties are set by the export).

We are seeing a similar behavior during a headless build, where the permissions do not get set correctly if we specify a directory: root.linux.gtk.x86.permissions.755 = jre/bin/ In this case, none of the files in the jre/bin folder have the correct permissions.
However if we specify just one file rather than the directory, the permissions get set correctly on just that file: root.linux.gtk.x86.permissions.755 = jre/bin/java This works.
This shouldn't be a problem anymore. However, I'm seeing a problem with setting the permissions on the launcher file. Will open another bug.

bug.short_desc: Trouble finding JREs if "-server" specified in eclipse.ini

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061214-1445
Steps To Reproduce: 1. download *.tar.gz 2. untar/-gz 3. right-click Eclipse.app; Show Package Contents 4. open Contents/MacOS/eclipse.ini 5. add -server to VM-arguments 6. close finder window 7. double-click Eclipse.app 8. create fresh workspace 9. Eclipse/Preferences/Java/Installed JREs
Observe the warning.
More information:
Moving to JDT/Debug

Created an attachment (id=55826) pic showing the warning
Contents of eclipse.ini:
-vmargs -Xdock:icon=../Resources/Eclipse.icns -XstartOnFirstThread -Xbootclasspath/p:../../../plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.debug_3.2.100.v20061211/jdi.jar -Xms40m -Xmx256m -server -Dorg.eclipse.swt.internal.carbon.smallFonts -Dorg.eclipse.swt.internal.carbon.noFocusRing

http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Java/Conceptual/JavaPropVMInfoRef/Articles/JavaVirtualMachineOptions.html -server
There is not a distinct server VM for Mac OS X. Although you may use the -server flag when invoking java, it does not start up a different VM, instead it starts the client VM that has been tuned for use in a server environment. This tuning includes:
* Using a different class list for the shared archive generation that does not include the GUI classes. * Increasing the size of the Java heap. * Increasing the size of the Eden generation. * Turns on thread local Eden garbage collection.
Works for me in I20070502-0010
verified that it does not occur in 3.3M7
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: BorderedNodeFigure#findFigureAt(int, int, TreeSearch) ignores exclusion set

Steps To Reproduce: This defect results in being able to drop the selected items inside the BorderedNodeFigure (if it's a compartment edit part) when this BorderedNodeFigure is part of a selection set.
This can be easily reproduced with Logic Example editor 1. Create a Circuit and throw a couple of shapes around the circuit. 2. Select all and start dragging the selected items on top of the circuit - note that curcuit compartment becomes highlighted as edit parts are about to be dropped inside it 3. Drop the items on top of the circuit.
Result: edit parts become children of the circuit, the circuit's location is changed.
Expected: since circuit is changing it's location as well as other edit parts being dragged, edit parts shouldn't go inside the circuit.

Created an attachment (id=55827) patch
Patch taking into account exclusion set
Committed the patch

bug.short_desc: [DataBinding] make setting of the default realm safe

long_desc.thetext: I would like to remove the setter for the default realm, only leaving the new method from bug 168153. This would make setting the default realm something you could rely on in the scope of a method.

(In reply to bug 168153 comment 3) > I like everything about this except for the name setDefault. > > setDefault is used frequently to set a singleton, which is not really what is > happening here.
The reason I named it setDefault() was because the Realm was then available via getDefault() and I couldn't come up with anything better.
> Perhaps Ream.perform(myRealm, new Runnable() {...}); > > But then why is this static? Wouldn't it be better for this to be a method on > Realm or am I missing something?
My reasoning for using a static method was to not confuse it with the syncExec and asynExec methods that exist on Realm. If perform was implemented on Realm we still need a way for the observable/binding/whatever to retrieve the Realm for the current thread statically.
Sorry, forgot to add Dave to the cc...

I see.
If we remove the setter, does that eliminate your concerns?

(In reply to comment #3) > If we remove the setter, does that eliminate your concerns?
Yes. How about this: public static void runWithDefault(Realm defaultRealm)
OK, I forgot the Runnable, but I am in favour of keeping it as a static method.

(In reply to comment #6) > ...I am in favour of keeping it as a static method.
Understood, but why?

I guess I should say why I prefer the instance method. Because if it's static, the syntax is:
Realm.runWithDefault(someRealm, someRunnable);
But you always have to have a realm instance, so there's a redundancy in the syntax.
someRealm.runWithDefault(someRunnable)
is more compact and eliminates the redundancy.
Also, some realm implementations (say, that encapsulate a File or a network stream that needs to be flushed) might want to do additional work around runWithDefault. Making it an instance method enables those Realm implementations to override the implementation and inject their custom behavior.

(In reply to comment #8) > Making it an instance method enables those Realm > implementations to override the implementation and inject their custom > behavior.
This is one reason why I'm not in favor of it being an instance method. We're setting the realm to be used when objects are constructed. This is not a function of a realm instance, this method is mainly for maintaining the default instance. The behavior shouldn't change depending upon the Realm being set IMHO.
Performed renaming Boris recommended in comment 6
This is in 3.3M5 correct? Are there any more changes needed before this can be closed?
I guess I forgot to close this.

bug.short_desc: "Wrapping Up" a Safe Holiday

long_desc.thetext:
Wrap Up a Safe Holiday
Yes, this is another reminder that with the joyous season of giving comes increased crime rates, especially theft. Keep in mind that crimes occur when a would-be criminal finds a "weak, accessible target". The distraction of holiday shopping, planning, traveling, visiting, etcetera is a perfect back drop for criminal activity. Not that that's going to prevent or change any of our plans. Right?
This is not an article about paranoia but about preparation! As a society, we need to be PROACTIVE rather than REACTIVE to our surroundings.
Crime happens when desire, opportunity, and a victim meet. With that in mind, let's add a few items to our planning list for this Holiday Shopping Season. They don't involve time or money, just safety-minded eyes and ears:
When you travel, know where you are going and how to get there and back. Check for construction detours; for longer trips, get a weather forecast.
If traveling out-of-state, most state law enforcement agencies provide road-and-highway information; check to see what conditions they report before leaving. Inform a family member where you will be and when to expect you back; give them your route if they don't know it.
Travel and conduct your business during daylight hours if possible. Lock doors and windows when getting into your car and keep them locked while driving.
If you have access to a cellular telephone, carry or take it.
If possible, know the emergency cell codes for the area you're in.
When driving, keep doors locked and windows rolled up. Maintain at least half a tank of fuel, and keep vehicle in good repair.
If you experience a breakdown, pull as far onto the shoulder as possible and turn your emergency flashers on. If you have a cellular phone, summon assistance from a reputable source or call for law enforcement response. Otherwise, raise your hood or tie a streamer to your antenna, and await assistance inside your locked vehicle.
If a stranger stops, speak to them through a partially rolled-down window, and ask them to go to a phone and call police or a tow service; do not exit your vehicle until a law enforcement officer or tow operator are on scene. On longer trips, be sure you have water, food, and blankets in the vehicle.
If involved in a property-damage collision in an unfamiliar or potentially unsafe location, do not open or exit your vehicle. If you have a cellular telephone, summon law enforcement. If not, acknowledge the accident by hand signal, and motion the other driver to proceed with you to a safe location (where there are other people and light) to exchange information. If unable to proceed, honk the horn to attract attention and ask a passer-by to summon police.
If signaled to stop by any vehicle other than a clearly marked law enforcement unit, acknowledge the signal, and wave the driver to follow you to a safe location (where there are other people and light). Drive within the speed limit and take the shortest possible route to the nearest safe place. If you have a cellular phone, dial 9-1-1, tell the call-taker you are being followed by an unmarked vehicle attempting to stop you, and ask them to send a marked law enforcement vehicle to your location.
When parking, roll up the windows, lock the vehicle, take the keys, and conceal valuables, preferably in the trunk. During hours of darkness, park and walk in lighted areas to the extent possible.
When returning to your vehicle, carry your keys in your hand and be ready to unlock the door and enter as quickly as possible. As you approach your vehicle, scan the area, glance underneath the vehicle, and take a quick look inside before entering.
While out and about, present an alert appearance.
Be aware of your surroundings; scan the area from time to time. Avoid concentrating so hard on shopping that you fail to keep track of your surroundings, others near you, or your personal property.
Wear conservative, comfortable clothing.
Grip carried items firmly and avoid leaving them unattended. Carry minimal cash and valuables, wear minimal jewelry.
Shop with friends or relatives if possible; there IS safety in numbers. As you shop, be alert in crowded places. Among pickpockets' favorites are revolving doors, jammed aisles, elevators, and public transportation stops and vehicles, especially at rush hour. Carry the day's most expensive purchases closest to your body, and don't carry so much you lose the ability to react quickly.
Keep a close eye on your children while shopping. Teach your children to go to a store clerk or security guard if they ever get separated from you in a store/mall, and be sure they know their first and last name so they can tell someone who they are. It's best to keep children under four (4) in a stroller. Children in shopping carts should be properly belted and seated in the child carrier area at all times never let your child stand in or push a shopping cart. If possible, leave your children with a baby-sitter while you are shopping. For holiday shopping, consider making arrangements with family or friends/neighbors, and take turns baby-sitting.
Return to your vehicle periodically to check on it and reduce the amount you are carrying and must keep track of. Store packages in the trunk or, if your vehicle doesn't have one, out of plain view (on the floorboard, under a blanket or clothes, etc). When possible, have purchases delivered instead of taking them with you; many businesses offer free delivery during the holiday shopping season. Ask for an escort to your car if you feel nervous.
Return to the mall or store for assistance if you spot suspicious activity near your vehicle. Stay alert while loading items into or out of the vehicle or arranging cargo stowage. If someone approaches, and you feel threatened, get in and lock up until they leave the area; if they loiter, drive away.
Using debit or credit cards is much safer than carrying a lot of cash. If the vendors you will visit don't take cards, consider obtaining traveler's checks which, unlike cash, can be replaced if lost or stolen. Visit ATM's only at well-lighted and populated locations; visit during daylight hours if possible.
Using the drive-up is usually safer than walking up or into a facility. Remember to scan around you as you make your withdrawal. Many ATMs now have "fisheye" mirrors mounted above the keyboard to enable you to view the entire surrounding area while conducting business; try to patronize ATMs so-equipped, and use the mirror!
If anyone is loitering, or you don't like their looks, go to another ATM. Stand such that those behind you cannot see your PIN as you enter it; your PIN should NEVER be written down on or carried with your ATM card. Be observant. Avoid dark areas, short-cuts, cul-de-sacs, and suspicious persons. Stay near light and people.
Be prepared to flee potential problems. If apprehensive about any location for any reason, leave. Consider carrying a whistle. Weapons are not recommended, and may be unlawful.
Your best defense may be as simple as being AWARE. Be aware of your surroundings, your belongings and bystanders in the vicinity. The above tips may reduce your chances of being victimized, but will not eliminate the possibility entirely. Identify areas of vulnerability and take action to remain safe!
Just in case you do find yourself in an awkward situation, or a victim, you'll want to report the incident. When this happens, be prepared to provide the following information:
* the race, sex, and approximate age, height and weight of the suspicious person(s)
* what the person(s) were wearing and any unique characteristics (tattoos, scars, etc.)
* if the person has left, how long ago, and in which direction did the person go
* the make, model, and color of the vehicle(s) involved
FBI Crime Rate statistics indicate that 1 out of every 25 people were a victim of crime in 2004 and 1 out of 250 people were a victim of a violent crime.
Your best defense against becoming a Victim of any crime is knowing how to reduce or remove the Opportunity segment of the Crime Triangle. If you prepare and practice, you will be ready for every eventuality
HAPPY SHOPPING, HAPPY TRAVELS AND HAPPY HOLIDAYS!
About the Author The author Kimberly Elliott is a free lance writer and marketing major. She is a wife, a mother of two, the CEO of a self defense training company that provides seminars, Private Investigative work and Corporate Safety Advice as well as a business partner of on-line safety, self defense and security products stores: www.ExecDefTech.com AND <a href="http://www.execdeftechss.com/" target="_blank
Copyright 2006 Executive Defense Technology, LLC

If the community articles component continues to get these spam article submissions we may have to do something about it. I think this is only the third spam submission I've seen so I don't think immediate action is necessary.

Reproduced the issue with Java 1.5.0_09 on WinXP.
While the RSE Runtime is all OK, the problem is with the RSE SDK and the RSE Examples packages. It appears that some bundles are modified in an incorrect manner by the pack200 condition / sign / pack200 / unpack200 steps. See also bug 163421 for a similar issue.
Reverting to unsigned packages on the update site for now. Sigh - signing and packing at the same time is _really_ playing with fate. Hope that these issues are being resolved in the UM and the Eclipse.org signing scripts as signing gets more popular.

Oh, no... another UM bug... ;)
BTW, I retried to install the unsigned version, and it is working OK now.

Reverted the TM update site to unsigned.
Verified with Sun JVM 1.4.2_12 on Linux, and 1.5.0_09 on Windows that all features can be installed from the update site properly.
closing.
Since Europa is to be signed, it seems strange to close this wihtout refering to a bug to fix the real problem...

Fair enough. The bug reference was in comment #1, and hopefully the fix for bug 168583 will fix this issue.
Note, though, that RSE 1.0.1 targets Eclipse 3.2.1, and we don't intend to sign & pack in this stream because we're not part of Callisto and the fix for bug 168583 needs to be retrieved as a patch before we can even think about signing. Thus this is being closed in terms of the 1.0.1 stream.
Our build scripts have been creating both signed and unsigned update sites since 2 months now, and hoping that the bugs which hinder consuming those are being resolved I'm optimistic that we can contribute signed builds to Europa.

bug.short_desc: [64] In New Project Wizard, items in the list can't be choosen

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1.Start eclipse 2.Click on File -> New -> Project
More information: In the list none of the different projects can be choosen. Java Project is choosen so I can click next and get an java project. But none of the others works. Running windows xp 64bit.
Have tried both eclipse-SDK-3.2.1-win32-x86_64 (M20060921-0945) and eclipse-SDK-3.2.1-win32 (M20060921-0945) with the exact same result. Have tried with booth the newest Java 6 (x64 and 32bit). Tried with java 5.
If i run eclipse eclipse-SDK-3.1.2-win32 (M20060118-1600) it works.
What do you mean by "none of the others works"? Do you get an error when you select other wizards, is the "Next" button disabled, or what? Any errors in the log file? (workspace/.metadata/.log).

I can't select for example "Plug-in Project" in the list. Nothing happens. I can't enfold (open) the project folders like "examples". I can press next and cancel. I can resize the window. I can press the helpbutton and get upp the help windows where I can click everything. Log is empty.
The exact same secenario occures if I now create the standard project, which will be created if I used press the next button, and then click New -> Other. In this dialog I can't select anything either.

bug.short_desc: [console] Pop console to front just once

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Start a long running process in Eclipse which logs a lot to the console 2. Search for something 3. Try to use the search pane.
More information: Every time the long running process prints something, the console pops to the front. I had to disable this in the prefs but now, I have to click the console to the front manually every time when I start something.
I'd like two things:
1. A hotkey to bring the console to the front 2. A prefs setting which allows to say "Console to front when a new process is launched" (instead of every time something is printed).

In regards to the hotkey issue:
The default key binding for showing the console view is Alt+Shift+Q,C. This key binding can be changed under Preferences->General->Keys.

There are preferences to toggle whether the console is displayed when output is written. In 3.3 we added buttons to the console toolbar to make the settings easier to change. Do not plan to add another preference to show console on launching.

Yes, that is a bit mysterious. I believe it is because we set the contribution to work for every outline view. I will leave this open in case there is a way to make that more specific, but not sure yet if Eclipse allows it.

bug.short_desc: [quick fix] Add quick fix for "Missing Build Path Variable ..."

long_desc.thetext: There is no quick fix for this error, yet.

There are at least 2 cases here:
1. <classpathentry kind="var" path="JUNIT_HOMErrrr/junit.jar"/> gives: Unbound classpath variable: 'JUNIT_HOMErrrr/junit.jar' in project J

bug.short_desc: It would be handy if I could have the console suspend an application in the debugger on certain output

long_desc.thetext:
3 features for the console and debugger:
1. A small text box where I could enter a regex or literal and the console would highlight anything that matches. Literals would be cheap enough to implement but if someone entered a complex regex, well, it's their fault...
2. In conjunction with this method, a small checkbox next to the textbox would allow the console to tell the debugger to suspend the application when text is matched.
3. Finally, lock console scrolling on match would be handy as well.
Marking as later for future consideration.

bug.short_desc: [indexing] Java Type Indicator eats CPU time

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061214-1445
Steps To Reproduce: 1. enter a big package in a library or project 2. take a break 3.
More information: basically, the system thread that calculates the decorators is on heavy business as soon as the "Java Type Indicator" in the preferences is activated and one chooses to open a package in the Project Explorer. It not only uses the CPU to the brim but also uses tons of memory. I've started realizing this since 3.3M4.

You are right. Decorations on class files inside JARs is really slow. It seems that using the search engine to find out the 'type' (class/interface/...) of the public type is not very efficient here.
My setup: - Fresh workspace (3.2.1, 3.3 M1, M3 and M4) started with JDK 1.5_10 - Turn off 'Java Type Indication' on General > Appearance > Label Decorators - create a test project, open the JRE container and expand 'java.io' (nothing else expanded) - Now turn on 'Java Type Indication' on General > Appearance > Label Decorators and wait for label decorations (for example on 'Closable' an interface decorator will appear)
With 3.2.1 this goes very quickly: There we used IType.getFlags() With 3.3 this takes very long: There we use the search engine as recommended by Philippe (see InterfaceIndicatorLabelDecorator)
This is not a problem for ICompilationUnits where using the search engine is very fast.
Please let me know if I should use again IType.getFlags() for class files or if this is a problem in the search engine. Performance traces attached.
Created an attachment (id=55954) snapshot 1
Created an attachment (id=55955) hot spots in 3.3 M4, with classfiles
Created an attachment (id=55956) hot spots in 3.3 M4, with source files
Created an attachment (id=55957) hot spots in 3.2.2, with class files

The problem is that index category table is not cached when table has more than 10,000 entries and unfortunately, this is the case for rt.jar (11,772 classes)... So, each search all type names request opens and reads the entire index file and makes this request slower...
Philippe, we need to talk about this issue to figure out what could be the best strategy in this case...

I've talked with Philippe about this issue... It seems we need to increase the limit of entries for cached category table.
I've made some measure on rt.jar of 1.4.2, 5.0 and 6.0 Sun VMs and here are the results I got: - 1.4.2: 'typeDecl' table has 8559 keys, estimated size = 1001540 bytes - 5.0: 'typeDecl' table has 11772 keys, estimated size = 1449332 bytes - 6.0: 'typeDecl' table has 14572 keys, estimated size = 1834954 bytes
So, it sounds like the limit needs to be pushed to at least 15,000 but perhaps more (20,000?) in prevision of next JDK versions...
As the size of the cached table is near multiplied by 2, we need to optimize table memory size to avoid memory footprint increasing. Bug 138309 already proposes some ways for this optimization.
I think we need to find some others, typically try to reduce the 'typeDecl' table by interning package names the same way it is done in TypeDeclarationPattern
See patch attached to bug 138309
Candidating the cache size increase for 3.2.2. If the cache is defeated, performances are terrible.
Released for 3.3 M5 in HEAD stream. Leave it opened as we'll backport this fix to R3_2_maintenance stream.
Released for 3.2.2 in R3_2_maintenance stream.

Looked at reducing the size of a type declarations table.
For JDK6, there are 15841 documents in the index. 14315 type declarations reference a single file & 256 reference more than 1 (anonymous types).
The category table size is mostly because of:
14571 keys, 670,766 characters (avg. size is 46 chars) -> ~1.5Mb for char[]s
As for the int[] values, it would be possible to save ~160K if we changed the format of the values from mostly int[1] to just an int. BUT this could not be done for reference tables that have very few, if any int[].length == 1, since it would take more space to store their int[]s. Is 160K out of 1.7Mb worth the added complexity of declaration vs. reference tables? I'm not convinced it is.
Clearly the majority of the space is in the keys, which the DiskIndex does not control. Even though we know 20-30 of the 46 characters of each key is the package name, we would lose any savings (to object headers) if we create other objects by splitting the char[] into 2-3 parts.
Unless we can come up with a way to replace the package name with an int in the key, I don't see how we can reduce the size of the table significantly.
We could create an interned name table & map a small number of names (ie. only package names) to ints. Then those names could be replaced with their int value in the keys of the index category tables.

(In reply to comment #14) > Since TypeDeclarationPattern already has an in-memory: > > // want to save space by interning the package names for each match > static PackageNameSet internedPackageNames = new PackageNameSet(1001); > > We should change it to a table that maps the name to an int & persist it. Then > each key in the TypeDeclarationPattern could substitute the int for the package > name. > I already thought about this possibility, but then there will be a problem when this set is rehashed, won't there?

Replace the set with a compound table that maps the package name to an int ID AND also stores the reverse lookup by holding onto a char[][], where each int ID is the index of the package name.
Adding a new package name would grow the char[][] and the added spot would be the int ID used to store the name in the lookup table.
This way its quick to find the ID associated with a package name and also quick to decode the name given its ID.

There was also a problem with the read of index file document names while performing the search all type names request. DiskIndex uses a cache for these names (cachedChunks) but this cache is systematically reset at the end of the query (stopQuery() method).
On the scenario given by Maxime (but using a 1.5 VM) I got following numbers to decorate all types: - 3.2.1: 1,1 second - 3.3 M5: 4,3 second (2,6 spent in DiskIndex.cacheDocumentNames())

Martin, is there any chance you can call:
searchAllTypeNames(char[][] qualifications, char[][] typeNames, ...)
Do you know all the types from the jar file up front or just 1 at a time?

The suggested optimization goes into the right direction but - it will not handle types like 'EntrySet' that are in 'HashMap$EntrySet.class' - JDT UI is the wrong area for this as it already tells JDT Core to only search in a CU or class file i.e. this performance optimization has to go into JDT Core so that all other clients can profit. From the Javadoc of the search engine it is not obvious that giving the type and package name is faster than providing the exact Java element in the scope
Frdric and I agreed to do the following: - JDT Core will do this optimization but will need more time for a clean and well tested fix. Hence this will be done for M6. - for M5 JDT UI will put in a fix along comment 20 for class files but with better handling for inner class types
Side Note: the fix that was put into 3.2.2 should probably go into its own bug report and this one be retargeted for 3.3 M6.
Committed workaround to HEAD. Will be in one of the next M5 candidate builds.

As suggested, I've opened separate bug 173279 for the category table entries number limit increase and set current target t 3.3 M6. I've changed the entry in R3_2_maintenance and HEAD buildnotes to reflect bug change...

Created an attachment (id=60909) Performance test results comparing different ways to get flags
I wrote a test corresponding to the initial test case and took some measures using different ways to get the flags on each class file of the java.io package of rt.jar (1.4.2).
Full results of these tests are in this attached file. Here's the summary:
Search all type names request: Time Heap ============================= 1) no package, no type name: 4.26s 9.46M 2) no package, no type name, case sensitive: 4.16s 12.05M 3) package name, no type name: 1.82s 9.64M 4) package name, no type name, case sensitive: 1.01s 9.6M 5) no package, type name: 0.521s 1.89M 6) no package, type name, case sensitive: 0.438s 1.94M 7) package, type name: 0.258s 4.67M 8) package, type name, case sensitive: 0.130s 4.67M
JavaModel getFlags(): ==================== 1) No class files opened: 0.035s 1.88M 1) All class files opened: 0.0068s 715

The two results to compare in comment 24 numbers are the test 8) of search all type names request and test 1) of java model.
As even the best search all type names request is still 4 times slower and consumes around 3 times more memory than the getFlags() when the java element is not opened, I do not think we can apply this change in JDT/Core directly in the getFlags() method as suggested during the JDT/Call 2 weeks ago.
The other solution would be to create a new API method equivalent to getFlags() and which would not populate the model (getModifiers() for example), but sounds like a little bit late 2 days before the API freeze...
My conclusion is that the fix must be done in JDT/UI land for now and leave the getFlags() method working as it does right now (i.e. open the java element to get the modifiers).
Note: searchAllTypeNames request has been already optimized (see releng performance tests results on last I20070313-1051 build: http://fullmoon.ottawa.ibm.com/downloads/drops/I20070313-1051/performance/performance.php) and I didn't find any easy other way to speed-up this request...

Created an attachment (id=60913) Patch to apply on InterfaceIndicatorLabelDecorator
With this patch CPU does no longer heat and I can see decorator appear in a reasonable amount of time (around 2s on my box)...

Created an attachment (id=60941) patch
I suggest to use this patch. JavaElementUtil.getMainType(unit) is not something to use (very inefficient). Please comment so I can release.

(In reply to comment #27) > Created an attachment (id=60941) [details] > patch > > I suggest to use this patch. JavaElementUtil.getMainType(unit) is not something > to use (very inefficient). Please comment so I can release. > Fine by me :-)

bug.short_desc: Eclipse update seems generally broken

long_desc.thetext:
My apologies if this sounds like a general squawk but... :)
Settings: choose mirrors automatically, no proxies
1. While trying to install Callisto, update hits a JAR/plugin it cannot find and fails completely. :( I'd expect it to go to another mirror on a per file basis and only fail if all mirrors had a problem.
1a. As a possible solution, I'd suggest a sort of manifest to drive the download, fingerprint every file in the distribution and associating it with the paths it will be projected down onto the disk. This would allow trivial verification and load balancing across servers and prevent anyone from lying about contents.
2. Updates conflict without suggesting any meaningful resolution. I licensed MyEclipse which apparently must patch certain bundles also provided by the Callisto aggregation. I get notices of conflicts with no hint about what the outcomes might be or what to do.
3. Updates are seemingly downloaded to the disk into seemingly arbitrary update sites. I roll the dice as to where an update will be put when two sites have the same plugin.
4. Creating extension locations by hand is wrong. As a user, I just want to keep plugins separate so I can copy them to different platforms trivially. I'm forced to create the dot files and structure by hand.
5. No "purge outdated plugins" is offered. I want to get rid of anything that's out of date in the locate to tidy up and recover disk space.

I don't think your problems qualify as 'generally broken'. A more appropriate description would be 'Update does have advanced features I would like it to have'. Namely:
1. Update currently fails if the plug-in it wants to download is not found on the site.
1a. Load ballancing is an interesting idea but does not exist at the moment. I don't even think many providers would like it - it is a bit unusual to cobble your feature from several servers (an Update version of Chuky :-)?
3. Actually, there are distinct rules as to where updates are downloaded. Updates to features go to sites where these features are. Features can also prereq to be collocated with other features ('collocation-affinity').
4. Creating extensions by hand may be a hassle, but is fairly trivial. I would not call that 'broken', just not as user-friendly. Note though that creating extensions is not a basic function.
5. "Purge outdated plugins" is a reasonable feature request. You can do a similar thing manually from the Configuration window by turning the visibility of disabled features on and deleting all features you don't want any more.

Point taken, but I've got to say the defects are certainly present. As delivered and instructed by the Eclipse.org documentation, failures happen regularly and with wipe-it-out-and-start-over consequences. What drove me to file the bug was having to go through numerous gyrations and inexplicable, opaque errors to get things going while following instructions and dialogs.
I lumped 5 defects into one report (my bad) and that's why I chose the title with "generally" in it. But individually, I think the items are certainly present and dangerous to users.
Honestly, I think the tipping point was that Eclipse + Callisto runs into problems and it may not be with update/install proper, but that's user's last point of reference, and from the feedback from the Eclipse runtime indistiguishable from Ecipse or the plugin provider.
Perhaps it would be better to file this under the indvidual Callisto projects. I'm certainly happy to log more refined issues, but it's hard to tell which particular plugin/feature is the offending install (my point about inexplicable outcomes here...) Given that many plugins can be dependent upon a particular plugin, it's hard to tell where to file the bug.
Advice?

In general, it helps when defects are specific, with a clear sequence of steps to reproduce them. Therefore, if you have problems after installing Callisto components through Update, a sequence using the offending projects would help us to zero on the cause.

How about this bug being titled: Failed JAR/plugin corrupts installation.
I've just had the failure come up a few times while getting EMF as a dependency of JST.
The result was that things appeared to work, and when it failed, I went looking in the configuration.
I wasn't able to resolve it there, so went to plugins, to find that I had .tmp files where my EMF jars should have been.
There was no way to resolve this other than clearing EMF out of features & plugins manually and re-installing from the Europa update site.
Now... how it should have worked is: - Re-try the plugin, possible on a different mirror - If that failed, mark the component as corrupt, or failed install - Filter failed components from showing up as installed when they're not. This would then allow me to install missing components.
Or..
In the Configuration tool, allow "Update..." on the component, to re-install it.

To add to my woes, what I thought would work to recover the situation didn't.
EMF was corrupt.
TPTP and WST depend on it.
I've had to go right back to the basic download.
To be clear, this is a BUG, not a feature request. Having update sites as the standard way to install features now, means that I have now wasted a good number of hours trying to install (and not exactly quickly) some basic tools. (rant over ;)

Marking helpwanted for now, see "Support Expectations" at: http://www.eclipse.org/mylar/users.php
Moving the setControl() call doesn't work. Unfortunately there doesn't seem to be an easy fix for the layout corruption.
I wonder if we can wrap the whole JIRA page into try catch block for now and set control to some dummy panel if it throw an exception

I think we would need to dispose all controls that have been created up to the point where the exception is raised, (i.e. iterate over all children of parent). Adding a dummy control then and disabling the Search button should work.

The problem with the patch is that connectors need to invoke setControl() before the exception occurs otherwise the widget can not be disposed.
I was thinking of adding a another Composite and use that as the parent widget that is passed to searchPage.createControl(). Good idea. I suggest reopening bug 165733 for that, as it is already assigned to you. But yes, let's hold off until post 1.0.1 for that change.

bug.short_desc: Include JRE for multiple platforms

long_desc.thetext:
The new 'Include JRE' option in PDE Product Export is great, however it allows to export a single JRE from the host platform's configured JREs. When exporting the product for multiple platforms, the same JRE is added to all packages.
Proposed solutions are:
1. Make the include jre and export for multiple platforms options mutually exclusive. 2. Check the target platform and include the jre only if the host and target matches. 3. (preferred) Move the include jre option in the product configuration editor and allow to specifiy the location of the jre for every target platform (like the launcher configuration). Assuming that the runnable JREs are available somewhere on the filesystem this allows to correctly export for multiple platforms and include the appropriate JRE.
I vote for option #3
you give people an inch and they want a mile ;) I'll work on this ;)
zzz

The product editor has been updated to include a section for bundling JREs.
See blog post: http://mea-bloga.blogspot.com/2007/01/jre-export-extreme-makeover-edition.html

bug.short_desc: Eclipse Team --> Checkout doesn't allow you to specify "force" -f option.

long_desc.thetext:
The CVS -f checkout option allows you to cope with the scenario when you've branched individual files on a need-to-branch basis. The -f checks out the branched version of a file if it exists on the specified branch. Otherwise it checks out the HEAD revision.
There is currently no option in the checkout dialog box to support this mode of operation.
The CVS "man" page shows this description of the -f option:
-f
When you specify a particular date or tag to cvs commands, they nor- mally ignore files that do not contain the tag (or did not exist prior to the date) that you specified. Use the -f option if you want files retrieved even when there is no match for the tag or date. (The most recent revision of the file will be used).
Note that even with -f, a tag that you specify must exist (that is, in some file, not necessary in every file). This is so that cvs will continue to give an error if you mistype a tag name.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 100738 ***
