bug.short_desc: provide mechanism for starring/tagging/bookmarking a task

long_desc.thetext:
Actually my tasklist has a lot of queries, tasks, from multiples repositories.
I usually work with "Focus on Workweek" to see what are my "most important" task.
However, it only shows tasks scheduled for this week, but I have some tasks that are unscheduled that I'd like to be always visible (so perhaps, I can remember that I need to schedule them ;).
What I ask is to be able to "star" a task, like when you "star" a message on gmail, so it will be always appear on "workweek" mode, even if it is not schedule for this week.
Actually, my workaround is to schedule it for this week, and reschedule every time time it goes red :)

The scheduling is actually intended to be used that way that starring is currently used. I'm marking P5 for now because we need a better understanding of how starring overlaps with scheduling in order to avoid doing something ad hoc.

It may help if we would have configurable time window for showing in work week mode.
There is a separate enhancement request to merge Activity view with Task list. So, that could be the one...
The point is that I don't want to schedule it, because I don't have any prevision.

I'm interested in this bug as well. What I'm looking for is something like a "personal level of interest". There are a lot of bugs in the repository that have high global priorities, but aren't necessarily of high priority to me. I'd like some sort of way of marking tasks as higher or lower priority in order to aid me in my scheduling.

It seems that there is now enough input that we should do something about this in the 2.0 timeframe. What I would like the people who have asked for this feature to identify is some specific details about which kinds of tasks would be put into this state. Gail and I chatted about this and came up with one concrete case: a task that's waiting on someone. Such a task should never go overdue and red, because you can't do anything about it until there is more input. However, you might want to have it stick in the Task List to remind you. In addition to Complete/Incomplete we could add a Waiting status, and this would have the effect of giving the task guaranteed visibility without it being scheduled.
In considering this please keep in mind that we are about to add a date range container view (bug 147084). So for any task status that we add like this we also have to know how it fits into that, since that view will be based on when tasks are completed or scheduled for. Without thinking about it more it seems that if a "Waiting" task is not scheduled it should be stuck on "Today" and move from day to day. If it gets scheduled it won't appear until the day it is scheduled for, but then instead of going red it will remain stuck in "Today" unless it is rescheduled.

My use cases:
- Wait for someone to decide something to schedule the bug (on my case this can take weeks or months, believe me or not...). - Follow some interesting discussion (on this case, perhaps it would be interesting to consider disabling showing of incoming tasks on workweek mode unless it is starred/pinned/etc.).
See also Eugene's bug#171828.
*** Bug 171828 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Very simple use case:
-A new bug comes in and I read it. -It looks interesting to me, so I would like to watch it. I add a "level 1 interesting" tag to it.

Another important use case: permanent local tasks.
I have a local task named for updating version info, with a context populated with readmes, changelogs, splashscreens, etc.
This task won't be completed never, as it is intended only as a reminder of what files I have to change each time I release a product version.

Willian: I have those too. I currently prefix them with "long: " so that I can find them all, and was thinking that they deserved a "long" or "recurring" state since. However, I rarely want to see those in the Focused mode until I need to work on them (e.g. day of). Would you want them to always show?

(In reply to comment #11) > Would you want them to always show?
Personally, yes.
Another use case is remembered now is a project I'm working on with a third party company, where I'm taking care of QA role.
This work is "intermittent", as there is not a exactly finish date (so I cannot schedule it for), but I'm working on it some days per week, as I receive new versions of their product and after some testing, I refuse it ;)
So I need this task to be on my workweek always, no matter how long it takes to finish.
This task's context contains a set of projects on CVS where I update the product releases they send to me.
Instead of a "waiting" status, I think it should be more appropriate to call it something more generic like "pin" as Eugene suggested.

If the final decision is to go with a boolean on/off kind of marking, I would prefer a more generic term like "flag" rather than "pin". I don't really have any reason to want to pin my tasks, but I do want to flag them. I just want a way to make the task stand out to me, regardless of how it is stored in the repository (i.e. personal interest vs. global priority).

Yes, the problem with the term "pin" is that it is about the UI action, not about changing the state of a task in a way that causes it to be pinned. So typically "flag" and "mark" are better words. Btw, I first want us to experiment with the date-range mode (bug 147083) and due dates (bug 152490) before settling on the design for this, because a lot of what determines that a task is relevant to see is when it needs to be done.

I think that idea of tagging had been suggested before. I now wonder if we can combine it with the highlighters:
-- user can create any number of arbitrary tags -- each tag can have custom color highlighting for the Task oList (but not for the other Eclipse decorators) -- each tag can be additionally configured to always show in the Task List -- quick find in the task list should allow to search by those tags

IHMO, mixing the pinning and tagging concepts makes it more complicated than it should be.
My original request is just: given a certain task, I want make it to be always relevant, no matter what.
The tagging concept is interesting too (I like it), but it in a perspective of generalizing the category concept, and would be handled on another bug.
Am I missing something?
It is hard to say. Tagging have certain semantic aspect, while pinning is just pinning.
See a related discussion on bug#180023.

We do not currently have a good and simple enough design outlined to get this to get it into 2.0. A challenge is that we are already allowing the user to control the following orthogonal properties of the Task List: * Priority/sorting * Scheduling/focus/presentations * Groupings via working sets
Adding another orthogonal dimension would affect one or more of these and would significantly complicate the UI. Moving for further consideration for post 2.0.
Missed one key property: * Incoming/outgoing

(In reply to comment #21) > Missed one key property: > * Incoming/outgoing
You also missed the tag/highlighter parameter.

The tag/highlight parameter is the subject of this bug (highlighters are not part of the supported distro). So yes, that would be a 5th one, and I'm concerned about having that many without a very clean story.

Hi, can you raise the priority for 3.0?
I'm really needing this starring thing.
Willian: are you currently using any work-arounds since you lack starring (e.g. marking something unread)? Work-around usage patterns are often telling of what the UI should end up like.

My current workaround is to use gmail stars on bugzilla email notifications ;) (seriously!)
Today I decided to start using a category and copying all my interesting bugzilla tasks into it. This will help me to separate what is important. Unfortunately I'll have to turn off the "Focus on workweek" every time I want to see them.

(In reply to comment #26) > My current workaround is to use gmail stars on bugzilla email notifications ;) > (seriously!)
Clearly we need to improve the UI so that you don't have to take such drastic measures that get you out of Eclipse ;) Fyi, for another GMail/inbox use case we have bug 177208.
I used to use starring in a similar way, but use scheduling instead now. Could you describe whether or not you are using scheduling, and if yes what it lacks that starring provides? I'm asking because starring is very closely related to scheduling since it means that you want to get to the item at some point and not have it disappear. That's not to say that it shouldn't be an attribute, but that the we might be able to add it in a way that dovetails with scheduling rather than being a separate dimension over the Task List (e.g. making a bit like "landmarking" in terms of scheduling, since the focus and context of the Task List are schedule based).

See comment#4, comment#10 and comment#11.
The problem is: I don't want to have them go red and have to schedule a date, but I want them to always appear on tasklist no matter what mode is on and with some type of decoration enough to distinguish them from "normal" tasks.
The "star" metaphor fits perfectly this case and actually is very familiar if you use gmail and/or google reader.

Willian: note that on the newsgroup we are exploring making them not go red, but stay blue (only tasks with an explicit due date would go red when overdue). In this scenario it would feel much more like starring. Once the discussion on that is wrapped up I will create a new bug report for that.

I don't think it will be quite the same. You will practically force users to local-schedule task to the past in order keep them visible, besides these tasks won't be distinguishable from the other tasks planned for given week, which seem quite huge drawback.

I agree with the last comment. Plus, scheduling tasks adds another level of complexity to something that should be a relatively simple process. If all you want to do is "flag" a task, then that is all that you should have to do. I guess the real discussion, then, is whether or not flagging/starring/pinning/whatever actually fits into Mylyn's vision of task management.
I do agree with comment#30 and comment#31.
*** Bug 154978 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

> In article <fcpbru$2sg$1@build.eclipse.org> Mik > Kersten<beatmik@acm.org> wrote: >> Mark, > >> Here is a quick summary of our current mechanisms for manually >> organizing your Task List; > >> QUERIES (aka Filters in JIRA): good because they're flexible, e.g. >> you can subdivide them as much as you want and name them in a way >> that simulates nesting. > >> CATEGORIES: useful for local tasks and for repository tasks with >> which you are not using a query. As you point out, much less useful >> if you are using queries since there will be duplication and no >> indication of what's already been added to the category. > >> WORKING SETS: useful for grouping sets of related categories and >> queries. > >> SCHEDULING: useful for presenting and ordering tasks in the order in >> which you want to work on them, both for your own tasks and for those >> of others. > >> What I think we need to better understand is your use case for >> tagging/categorizing the tasks. For example, what would you name >> such categories? When would you move things into them? How would >> this overlap with the use of Scheduled For dates? > >> We have to proceed extremely carefully in adding any arbitrary >> attribute UI to the Task List because we already have 4 orthogonal >> mechanisms for organizing tasks. We also have better support for >> subtasks now, and a key goal of the Task List is to stay simple by >> minimizing hierarchy. If we allow containers to cascade in addition >> to supporting subtasks, the UI and interaction would become >> considerably more complicated.
Mark Phippard wrote:
> First let me say I do not pretend to have an answer. I guess in some > ways what I want to do ought to be doable in my issue tracker, it just > isn't. Also, when working in a collaborative open source world you > might want to do some organizing that you do not push into the issue > tracker. Theexisting scheduling features are a good example of this. > > My scenario seems simple (to me). I have a query that pulls down a > number of issues. Let's say it is all open tasks with the 1.x > milestone. I have 30 tasks. I might not do any of them myself. I > wanted to organizethem in random ways. Basically I just wanted to > make some groups: > > Critical - hard > Critical - medium > Deferrable > Needs Scoping > > etc... > > Then assign these 30 tasks to one of the groups. I started out using > categories but quickly realized there was no way to know what tasks I > hadalready categorized. > > One way to approach this might be to be able to apply Web-2.0 style > tags to tasks. If you could see a comma separated list of tags > assigned in the task list you would at least know if you had assigned > one or not. You could then offer a view that grouped by tag. This > might be more flexibleassuming you can assign more than one tag.

Could all people interested in this feature please post the set of all the tags that they would regularly use for tasks? When doing so also please describe how you do or do not use the scheduling facilities. We have the following mechanisms, each of which can be extended to support this behavior: 1) Personal scheduling (exists, can be extended, simplest) 2) Personal status (does not exist, could be user extensible, significant complexity added) 3) Arbitrary attributes (does not exist, by definition user extensible, very significant complexity added)
Starring can simply be implemented by having a star/sticky state for the scheduling rules for the task. This would mean that it doesn't go red, but does have guaranteed visibility. You can get this now for tasks without shared due dates (e.g. local tasks) by setting their due date in the past.
Above Mark provided an "effort" schema that he would like to use. This could be added as a Personal Status type schema, either by adding a new property or by extending status and allowing personal status to be managed for a task, similarly to how we allow personal and shared due dates. Here is a dump of other potentially valuable personal status values: * Incomplete * Complete * In progress * Waiting on someone else * Hard * Very hard * Deferrable * Needs scoping * Needs review
There's also the GTD style schemas which I've used considerably in the past (e.g., someday/maybe, read/review, reference).
Some of these have attributes overlap with scheduling and with shared status. Before we choose any of the 1-3 approaches listed above to addressing this need, it would be great to get people's feedback of the attributes/values that they would use frequently so that we can figure out how they overlap with the current task schema, how we need to extend that schema or make it extensible, then separately figure out how best to present that in the UI.

Mik, can you please elaborate what are you trying to do here? It looks like you attempting to substitute feature B (i.e. some kind of universal categorization) instead of feature A (arbitrary tagging) requested by the users.
Anyways, here are couple parallel categorizations that I am constantly missing:
- interesting, important, submitted patch, needs research, should comment - tag tasks per client. I don't want to put those into a separate folders or working sets and they could be local tasks and come from multiple repositories

Eugene: I am not trying to substitute anything, I am asking everyone interested in tagging to list their tags, use cases, and the ways they leverage existing functionality so that we can have enough date for a design discussion on this before deciding what the features (or substitutions) are. Your listing is exactly what I was after. Also, it's good that you brought up working sets, since they are currently are an arbitrary tagging mechanism (for queries and categories, not tasks just yet). Regarding the per-client tagging, could you elaborate on limitations of doing this via categories and Go Into (a sort of tagging), and more on why you don't use working sets for per-client tagging (I do, and have local tasks in working sets as well). Also, whether and how much you use the Focused mode.

I think I'd want to be able to apply arbitrary tags based on whatever "system" I was currently working with. For example, maybe I intend to assign a set of tasks to 5 resources and I just want to be able to see what the assignments look like. I could create the tags, move the tasks around and then start editing/assigning them. Then I might just get rid of the tags.
For me a key is knowing what I have tagged and what I haven't.

(In reply to comment #37) > Eugene: I am not trying to substitute anything, I am asking everyone interested > in tagging to list their tags, use cases,
I may be missing something, because use case is to allow to assign arbitrary tags to any tasks (actually more then one tag per task). Mark gave good analogy to Web 2.0 tagging.
Given the time it already took to bring this feature in and amount of discussion, I wonder if you are convinced that it should not be part of Mylyn. In this case, please provide functionality from bug 199818, so it would be possible to implement this tagging feature as an external value added feature.
> Also, it's good that you brought up working sets, > since they are currently are an arbitrary tagging mechanism (for queries and > categories, not tasks just yet).
I disagree with that. Working sets are arbitrary grouping - not tagging.
> Regarding the per-client tagging, could you > elaborate on limitations of doing this via categories and Go Into (a sort of > tagging), and more on why you don't use working sets for per-client tagging > (I do, and have local tasks in working sets as well).
Like I said, it is orthogonal to categories or working sets. I have category for all local tasks (so they all have characteristics of some personal task) and I don't want to create multiple categories because it will clutter task list structure (actually I am not alone on this, given bug 195047, where you turned down my patch). On top of this there are tasks that related to same client but they come from different repositories (for example some Mylyn features may require fixes in SWT/JFace, so I need to track Mylyn issue and corresponding issue for SWT/JFace, it is just so happens that they are in same bugzilla, but there are many projects that aren't that lucky). If you think about it, it is somehow similar to Scheduled presentation.
> Also, whether and how much you use the Focused mode.
I am using focused mode all the time. Otherwise task list is completely unmanageable with ~10k tasks in it.
BTW, once we'll get the tagging it would be quite natural to allow to group tags into the working sets (tag working sets)...

Mark: yes, just the ability to provide arbitrary tagging is definitely on the board. What I'm asking is for everyone interested in the arbitrary tagging to list the tags they would like to use so that we can figure out if/how/where they relate to current schemas we support (e.g. status, scheduling) and with connectors-specific schemas that might overlap and need a good UI to determine a good persona/shared split. What makes this even more interesting is that Mylyn is intended to support task repositories that already have tagging mechanisms (e.g. Google Code, Outlook 2007).
Eugene: Working Sets *are* a tagging mechanism by any standard definition of tagging. The current working set UI makes them feel more like grouping, but all we have to do is relax the constraint that tasks can't be included in a working set to change that. Then you could easily do something like have a working set called Submitted Patch, right+click a task to add it to that working set, and make a presentation that showed working set / tag nodes under repositories (one of your use cases) or under queries (one of Mark's). Since we have already have some support for working sets we have to consider it in conjunction with additional tagging mechanisms.
Or we might be able to get away with something along the lines of the following: * Working Sets are a tagging mechanism restricted to Task List containers (categories & queries) * Task Tags are a tagging mechanism restricted to tasks
But note that we are walking a slipper slope here, because we could easily end up with a valid Task List presentation that looked like this:
Task List + Working Set (e.g. Mylyn) + Query (e.g. All Mine) + Grouping (e.g. Reporter) + User Tag (e.g. Submitted Patch) + Task + Sub Task
That could make for a very complex UI. I'm trying very hard to preserve the Task List's easy of use as a grouped list or a grouped tree for Connectors that support sub tasks (http://wiki.eclipse.org/Mylyn_Focused_UI_Design#Avoid_Hierarchies ) and will continue doing so and avoid band-aid solutions (e.g. the highlighters I added way back) that don't take into account UI complexity and the experiences of UIs that went down this road (e.g. Microsoft Project's deep hierarchies, Microsoft Outlook's user-defined tag/attribute based nesting ability) .
But that's not to say that we won't integrate arbitrary tagging, I actually think that we will figure out the way to do it and hope that we make progress on that in the 2.2 timeframe. So please keep the use cases coming. Tree mock-ups of what your Task List currently looks like and what you want it too look like would also be helpful.

(In reply to comment #41) > Eugene: Working Sets *are* a tagging mechanism by any standard definition of > tagging.
I don't know about any standard definition. But from the implementation point of view working set is a container that can contain certain things. On a contrary - tag is a property of those certain things and not a container. Hence tagging is a more flexible mechanism, because you can build more just one aggregation model based on the same data and if add working sets on top of tags it would be very customizable.
> But note that we are walking a slipper slope here, because we could easily end > up with a valid Task List presentation that looked like this: > > Task List > + Working Set (e.g. Mylyn) > + Query (e.g. All Mine) > + Grouping (e.g. Reporter) > + User Tag (e.g. Submitted Patch) > + Task > + Sub Task
That is not necessary. With tag-based model it would look like this:
- Tag Working set - Tag (group) - Task, subtask, etc

There are three features I would like in the task list.
1. Some notion of starring to make a task sticky. My most common case for this is a task like the one represented by this bug. It came in, I want to add a response, but it feels awkward to schedule it because I don't know if I will find time to respond. I end up scheduling the task, and rescheduling it, etc. If I schedule it, it feels wrong that it ever goes "red" because to me its not overdue; nothing catastrophic will happen if I don't respond! [Note, Mik mentions getting guaranteed visibility for local tasks re. setting a due date in the past - I think this mixes the semantics of "due dateness" with a desired effect ("seeing it") and should be avoided in the task list. If the norm becomes using a feature with clear semantics (like due date) to do another behaviour, the meaning of the feature dilutes quickly. I'm in trouble if I start thinking I can ignore due date :)]
2. An ability to put in status, particularly "waiting for input" and "review". I would want to use these to order presentation of tasks and/or help choose what to work on. In particular, "waiting for input" would be useful to sort lower and I would like to be able to hover and see that status.
3. An ability to add tags to tasks to provide different categorizations. I'd like to use these tags for searching to find tasks completed in task or scheduled in future. Very much in the gmail style - show me all tasks meeting tags x, y and z. I would use this for recall and would not want to tag all tasks.

(In reply to comment #42) > I don't know about any standard definition. But from the implementation point of > view working set is a container that can contain certain things. On a contrary - > tag is a property of those certain things and not a container.
Eugene: sorry, by "standard definition" I was thinking Wikipedia and should have linked: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tag_%28metadata%29 I don't want to clutter the discussion with implementation detail, but Eclipse's working sets are not a containment mechanism (see comment#41 and I will send you an email elaborating). They can support an Task List element being associated with one or more of a flat set of tags and have no containment or hierarchy style restrictions about the cardinality of the association (support many-to-many associations of task to working set).
I am not saying that in terms of the current UI working sets are the right mechanism for implementing some of the tag use cases discussed. Just that we already have a tag mechanism in place and have to very clearly understand the overlap of the two (e.g. does each operate on all elements in the Task List or not).
> That is not necessary. With tag-based model it would look like this: > > - Tag Working set > - Tag (group) > - Task, subtask, etc
Thanks, this kind of example is exactly what we need to be iterating on. What I'm wondering about it is whether it implies that groups == tags (a sort of automatic variety) or whether it would impose the need to tag most tags, or whether it would require automatic tagging (e.g. everything in a category gets tagged). What would be very helpful is if you could iterate on this with a concrete example of your Task List or a sample Task List would look with this structure, by writing out a dozen or so nodes of the structure.
(In reply to comment #43) > There are three features I would like in the task list. > > 1. Some notion of starring to make a task sticky.
Yup, this seems to be one of the most important things for us to add and the original description of the bug. Do you see stickiness as more of a scheduling property (e.g. Schedule for -> Sticky/Starred/Important) or as a task Status (e.g. Important/Waiting/Review) or as it's own orthogonal thing? The guaranteed visibility rules in the Task List are all about when you should get to addressing the item, and sticky tasks will also need to be sorted in an intuitive way. So the implications are something like: 1) Scheduling: I will get to this task whenever I can, but it does not go overdue. To make this explicit, and differ them from tasks that are scheduled for this week, these tasks will likely need a different foreground color decoration or a star icon overlay. 2) Status: Tasks completed today already have a guaranteed visibility rule, so this approach could be reasonable as well, although conceptually more complex, and it would mean that we allow local status to be set on repository tasks, and add a popup menu mechanism for setting status. This would probalby require an icon overlay to make the status explicit (i.e. explain why the task is sticking). 3) Custom: most similar to some of the Google UIs where starring is independent and first class. Results in another orthogonal attribute that tasks can have which means more complexity, but could be intuitive enough if we figure out a could overlap with arbitrary attributes/tags.
> I think this mixes the semantics of "due dateness" with a desired > effect ("seeing it") and should be avoided in the task list. If the norm becomes > using a feature with clear semantics (like due date) to do another behaviour, > the meaning of the feature dilutes quickly. I'm in trouble if I start thinking I > can ignore due date :)]
Agree and don't recommend this approach, but was curious what work-arounds others are using for stickiness because work-arounds are possible and are always informative of what the final solution should be like since they provide data on how people actually handle the use case, and not how they imagine they will handle it if given a new facility. Here are my work-arounds: 1) Schedule for Sunday. This makes the task sticky without making it go red. Cost is having to reschedule it once every 7 days. Limitation is that works for repository tasks that are not closed. 2) Write notes to put the task into an outgoing state. I do this all the time, and tend to write in tags in angle brackets (e.g. [review], [need more input], [later], [important]). Limitation is that it only works for repository tasks.
Just curious, if people aren't using the above could they try them as an interim solution? They meet every starring use case that I'm aware of so it would be good to know what use cases they don't meet, and then get some impressions on how people would like the UI to be. For example, (2) provides a very visible decoration of stickiness with the outgoing arrow, do people want a more or less visible decoration?
> 2. An ability to put in status, particularly "waiting for input" and "review". I > would want to use these to order presentation of tasks and/or help choose what > to work on. In particular, "waiting for input" would be useful to sort lower and > I would like to be able to hover and see that status.
+1 for my own use. Are you wanting this for repository tasks, i.e. having your own status shadown repository task status?
> 3. An ability to add tags to tasks to provide different categorizations. I'd > like to use these tags for searching to find tasks completed in task or > scheduled in future. Very much in the gmail style - show me all tasks meeting > tags x, y and z. I would use this for recall and would not want to tag all > tasks.
+1 Whatever the mechanism we end up with we should support this. This is bug 165391, which is dependent on this bug and scheduled for 3.0. If possible could you provide a dump of the tags that you would use (comment#35)?
What I'll do after Friday's 2.1 release is compile all of the proposals and listings on this bug into a wiki page that describes the current schema, sorting and visibility rules, as well as focused mode rules. We can then iterate on growing it, improving it, and making it more extensible. Marking for 2.2 because we need to make progress on the design of this at minimum, since some points in the design could result in very significant changes in the Task List's UI and conceptual model.

(In reply to comment #44) > Eugene: sorry, by "standard definition" I was thinking Wikipedia and should have > linked: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tag_%28metadata%29 I don't want to > clutter the discussion with implementation detail, but Eclipse's working sets > are not a containment mechanism (see comment#41 and I will send you an email > elaborating).
The containment property of the working sets is written in sto... its API. See the following method:
IAdaptable[] org.eclipse.ui.IWorkingSet.getElements()
I do see how working sets could be useful to work with tags, but tags themselves should be lower level beyond working sets (i.e. there could be tags that don't need to be in any working set). The major reason is to keep number of working sets small while dealing with large number of tags.
> Thanks, this kind of example is exactly what we need to be iterating on. What > I'm wondering about it is whether it implies that groups == tags (a sort of > automatic variety) or whether it would impose the need to tag most tags, or > whether it would require automatic tagging (e.g. everything in a category gets > tagged).
Once again, categories should stay completely orthogonal from tags. Though I do see some potentially useful features around automatic tagging (you may want to look at the FogBugz features that does this kind of stuff of sorting/tagging incoming tasks). Also, we could provide a special presentation that would show the "task cloud" so user would see the tag-based grouping.
> What would be very helpful is if you could iterate on this with a > concrete example of your Task List or a sample Task List would look with this > structure, by writing out a dozen or so nodes of the structure.
I'll see what I can do.
Moving bugs that depend on this (as per Mozilla convention on depends on vs. blocks).

My current understanding of these issues:
Working sets should delineate resource sources and act as virtual boundaries Eclipse wide (Package Explorer, Task List, and potentially the Synchronize view bug#163479, bug#196092). I include the current notion of Category as a 'source'.
Tags simply aid personal arbitrary grouping/finding, are not working set specific. Dynamic categories could be formed based on simple keyword inclusion/exclusion (which in turn could be added to working sets). A few tags I personally would use: * petpeeves - tasks that really bug me personally and I'd really like to fix or see fixed * quickfix - tasks that should be a quick fix if I have a minute or two to spare * bugzilla31 - tasks requesting features or fixes for an unsupported repository (Bugzilla 3.1)
States are interpreted and each have associated presentation rules in the Task List. Could be implemented as 'special' tags. Somewhat related to the gtd Tickler file perhaps where states are somewhat like 'reasons' for the reminder/stickiness. Gail, it is interesting you mention that it could be used to consider what to do next, similar to action items in gtd parlance. I often use the notes section as my action items list for a task. If this was more structured with [State][ Description] lines the last state could propagate to the ui affecting icon overlay, sorting etc.
Here is somehow related screencast about tag-based classifications and searching (applied to photo images). http://channel9.msdn.com/Media/PhotoGallery.html

This discussion is getting very interesting ;)
(In reply to comment #39) > I disagree with that. Working sets are arbitrary grouping - not tagging.
A bit off-topic curiosity: what was the main driver to bring working sets into Mylyn? It is cool stuff, but I never used them and I still don't know why I would use.
I only use working sets in one place: to group related projects in the package explorer. But I'm considering giving up even for that, and returning to using multiples workspaces, because definitely Eclipse/JDT/PDE does not scale well to large workspaces.
BTW, I think the working set metaphor is a complete failure in Eclipse: I never understand why you have Resource, Java, C++, Script, etc. working sets, if all of them are just buckets where you throw files into. Until some milestones ago (it was fixed), the team/CVS only allowed you to checkout into a "resource working set", even if a "java working set" has practically the same meaning (and you could not convert from one to another!). I have another ones here in my installation, like breakpoint, plugin working sets and I have absolutely no idea why I would use them too. The UI for working sets is complex, it takes a lot of clicks to enter the configuration dialog and insert something into it.
I want the tool working for me, not the contrary. Personally, I like simplicity. I admire gmail for having turned something that would be a maintenance nightmare (a ~3GB webmail where you never needs to delete anything) into something that made me give up the desktop email client. And they made it by:
1 - keeping the UI organizational elements at minimum: you have only one very flexible structure: a tag. They present tags as top level elements, so you can see them as categories or folders.
Some people see the fact that you cannot create nested folders as a disadvantage, but I like it. For big amount of data, I think hierarchical structures doesn't work. Eugene and Mik said they have task lists with thousands of elements, and I think this is the default scenario for anyone who works using bugtracking systems. I don't see a hierarchical structure with more than 2 levels working in scenarios like this.
2 - Their "search, don't sort" mantra, or something like this ;) For advanced uses/users, they use/abuse of the search, and this is something I think could be more explored by Mylyn.
https://mail.google.com/support/bin/answer.py?answer=7190
I don't know I everyone cc'd on this bug knows/uses this feature. I think this is one use case of bug#165391. We could, for example type "is:unread" on task list filter, and have it automagically brings only unread things. Or make combinations, like "is:unread and is:starred and tag:bugday".
(In reply to comment #41) > good persona/shared split. What makes this even more interesting is that Mylyn > is intended to support task repositories that already have tagging mechanisms > (e.g. Google Code, Outlook 2007).
Now that you said this, I'm wondering who we would handle these cases. Would the repository tag concept be totally integrated with the task list one, i.e., for a certain task, you can only tag what is permitted by the repository? I just figured out that in bugzilla the keyword concept is exactly what we can call a "server side" tag mechanism.
If the tag system is determined by the task repository, you won't be able to tag things arbitrarily according to your personal use.
> Eugene: Working Sets *are* a tagging mechanism by any standard definition of > tagging. The current working set UI makes them feel more like grouping, but all > we have to do is relax the constraint that tasks can't be included in a working > set to change that.
Agree. The key problem with working sets as tags is the UI, like I explained before. You can't right-click a task and select a working set to insert into, although I think this would be easy to implement.
> But note that we are walking a slipper slope here, because we could easily end > up with a valid Task List presentation that looked like this: > > Task List > + Working Set (e.g. Mylyn) > + Query (e.g. All Mine) > + Grouping (e.g. Reporter) > + User Tag (e.g. Submitted Patch) > + Task > + Sub Task
This is what I'm afraid of. I think everyone here presented use cases slightly different from each other, and everyone likes some metaphor more than the others, but essentially they are the same. Like in the gmail example, we could have a simple structure serving different purposes.
Regarding grouping and tagging, the category system fits my needs today because:
- If I want to group tasks, like "Pending patches", I can create a category and throw them there. - If I want to tag something, the existing category system lets me associate the same task to different categories, although some UI polish is necessary. IMHO, instead of "move to category", it could be a menu called "Categories" with checked items for each existing category, like in google reader.
Regarding the working set vs. tag, I could see each category implemented as a working set, and like now, the task list could let me enable/disable the categories/working sets I want to see as top level elements.
The starring stuff could be some kind of "special" category (implemented as), but with special UI treatment.

(In reply to comment #42) > I don't know about any standard definition. But from the implementation point of > view working set is a container that can contain certain things. On a contrary - > tag is a property of those certain things and not a container.
It depends on the point of view. The google products use tags as containers, even presents them like containers (although the last version of google docs turned them back into folders, visually speaking).
(In reply to comment #43) > There are three features I would like in the task list.
Completelly agree.
> 3. An ability to add tags to tasks to provide different categorizations. I'd > like to use these tags for searching to find tasks completed in task or > scheduled in future. Very much in the gmail style - show me all tasks meeting > tags x, y and z. I would use this for recall and would not want to tag all > tasks.
As I said in the previous comment, actually I create a category and copy these tasks. If tags were implemented as categories, these would be categories that I don't want to be visible as top level elements, only for search.
(In reply to comment #44) > Yup, this seems to be one of the most important things for us to add and the > original description of the bug. Do you see stickiness as more of a scheduling > property (e.g. Schedule for -> Sticky/Starred/Important) or as a task Status > (e.g. Important/Waiting/Review) or as it's own orthogonal thing?
For me, it depends. Sometimes I want to "star" it because I need to respond, but not now, neither I want to schedule it. I just want a visual signal to remember me next time I look at.
Sometime I want to mark it "important". I could mark this bug report as important, and every time it gets updated I can see it immediately in the middle of all other tasks, without the need to created a special folder/category/tag for it.
> 3) Custom: most similar to some of the Google UIs where starring is independent > and first class.
What makes the "star" feature so cool, is that google make it a first class citizen. It is simple and useful.

(In reply to comment #49) > A bit off-topic curiosity: what was the main driver to bring working sets into > Mylyn? It is cool stuff, but I never used them and I still don't know why I > would use.
Main reason is to be able to hide some subsets of the task list and quickly jump between those subsets.
> The UI for working sets is complex, it takes a lot of > clicks to enter the configuration dialog and insert something into it.
I was satisfied with the initial result before Mik added resources into the purely task working set. Unfortunately there are other limitations, such as inability to include specific tasks.
> 1 - keeping the UI organizational elements at minimum: you have only one very > flexible structure: a tag. They present tags as top level elements, so you can > see them as categories or folders.
What is missing there is category of tags. You can't efficiently deal with more then 5..6 tags if you can't organize them into some groups.
> 2 - Their "search, don't sort" mantra, or something like this ;) For advanced > uses/users, they use/abuse of the search, and this is something I think could be > more explored by Mylyn. > https://mail.google.com/support/bin/answer.py?answer=7190
That works ok for monitoring or browsing, but barely useful for planning when tasks need to be sorted between various buckets.
> Now that you said this, I'm wondering who we would handle these cases. Would the > repository tag concept be totally integrated with the task list one,
not at all
> Agree. The key problem with working sets as tags is the UI, like I explained > before. You can't right-click a task and select a working set to insert into, > although I think this would be easy to implement.
I don't think that is an issue at all. You don't need to switch between many sets. Usually number is less then dozen and UI issues are also exaggerated given number of the task-related artifacts you can include into any given working set (ignoring resource artifacts, which should not be there to begin with).
> This is what I'm afraid of. I think everyone here presented use cases slightly > different from each other, and everyone likes some metaphor more than the > others, but essentially they are the same. Like in the gmail example, we could > have a simple structure serving different purposes.
I think it is a big mistake to craft task management UI after gmail. Use cases are quite different.
> - If I want to group tasks, like "Pending patches", I can create a category and > throw them there.
That don't work too well for overlapping categories. Note that even gmail allows to assign multiple tags to any given message.

(In reply to comment #50) > It depends on the point of view. The google products use tags as containers, > even presents them like containers (although the last version of google docs > turned them back into folders, visually speaking).
Yes it does depends on the point of view. Google does present tags as containers, but on gmail they look and feel more like shortcuts to searches. The biggest problem in Mylyn is that both containers and working sets are aggregation collections, while tags should be property of the given entry. For instance, task can be dropped from query at any time, hence loosing the containment relationship.

Willian: those are some excellent points in comment#49 and comment#50. Just a quick reply on the question of working sets for now, because it sounds like our current design is meant to address the very usability problem that you're having with working sets. Mylyn's working sets can contain different kinds of elements (currently recommended use is task containers and projects), and don't require you to use Eclipse's typed working sets. It would be great if you could try them out since they are another way of categorizing the Task List: see "Creating working sets" in http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/java/library/j-mylyn1/ for details.
Also note that before getting to this I'll be working on improving the scheduling/focus/visibility facilities for tasks, since there is some overlap, so those interested should consider adding themselves as CCs on bug 206566.
This most likely needs to be pushed off to 2.3. UI improvements for 2.2 will be focused on scheduling (bug 206566), the task archive (bug 181388), and task editor scalability (bug 206568).

bug.short_desc: Problems with exporting product in presence of linked projects.

long_desc.thetext:
I find myself closing my imported plugins and fragments before doing a product-export, because otherwise the build does not complete normally. Given Bug 166176 in 3.3, this is really a pain.
Ben

Ben, I am not sure I understand what you are trying to do nor why it's a problem.
For everything related to self-hosting in PDE, workspace projects take precedence over target plug-in counterparts.
What is special about this case? and why are workspace plug-ins not desired? and how can we tell which workspace plug-ins you want and which you don't?

Sorry for not being more descriptive, I was very frustrated yesterday...
I have the following setup: - Target Platform set to RCP 3.3 M4 - Imported Target Platform Plugins with linked content - Got my own set of plugins which form a RCP application - RCP application is based on features with a product configuration file
I was under the impression that this bug was already known to PDE for a while (in fact I have experienced it for a long time but never felt like filing a bug because closing projects worked in 3.2).
So, whenever I do a Product Export from the product config file, the export fails if any of the used plugins exists in the workspace as imported with linked content (I am not sure if this problem is related to the "linked" thing or not).
With failing I mean that all the RCP plugins end up missing the class-files in their JARs. I have no idea why this is happening at all, but as soon as I close the workspace plugins belonging to RCP, everything goes fine.

> So, whenever I do a Product Export from the product config file, the export > fails if any of the used plugins exists in the workspace as imported with > linked content (I am not sure if this problem is related to the "linked" thing > or not).
Is to be read as:
So, whenever I do a Product Export from the product config file, the export fails if any of the plugins are open that have been imported from the target platform as "Project with linked content" (I am not sure if this problem is related to the "linked" thing or not).

That's what I figured. PDE/Build has a (known) problem with linked content.
I think it's time to get this issue resolved.
PDE/UI will be happy to pass in any information pde/build needs to support this scenario.

Andrew, I thought you fixed something to that extent earlier this year? Am I getting confused with something else? Also when I imported ICU as a linked plug-in and then exported it, I got a strange result: all the files listed in project but not the jar. It made me thinking that we may need PDE UI to tell us where is the actual jar when the plugin is jar'ed.
We fixed bug 158589 in M3. It was to do with use incorrectly building the classpath in the case of linked content. Ben, are you using 3.3M3 or later?

I was using M4. But saw this in every milestone of 3.3.
bug 158589 is very interesting for me, because it explains why I see different results using 3.2 (build fails with error message) compared to 3.3 (build runs but linked plugins end up missing their jars as Pascal mentions).

Ahh, I expect that we need special handling for this case in the generated assembly/packaging scripts. Such projects would likely be considered binary by pde.build (ie no build.properties file) and are likely just copied straight over. We probably need to explicitly add copy tasks for the linked content.
I think this should be re-investigated and considered in 3.4
*** Bug 206398 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: [dnd] Copy/paste a folder from package explorer does not copy its contents

long_desc.thetext: RSE 1.0.1: if you copy some folder on package explorer, and paste it on a SFTP server, it only creates the folder, but does not copy its contents recursively too.
We should add the Project Explorer, Common Navigator and Package Explorer to the list of views supported for Drag&Drop as well as Copy&Paste.

(In reply to comment #1) > We should add the Project Explorer, Common Navigator and Package Explorer to > the list of views supported for Drag&Drop as well as Copy&Paste. >
Do you mean it works with the "normal" Navigator view? (Sorry, I don't have a server here at work to test it now...)

This should now be fixed. There were a couple problems here that may account for other defects. The key problem I found was that refreshLocal() (done during the copy) could conflict with other resource locking rules - causing an exception that prevented the operation from completing. To resolve this problem, I've (1) changed the SystemDNDTransferRunnable to be a WorkspaceJob rather than a Job and (2) made sure that refreshLocal() is only called if the src resource is out of synch in the workspace.

bug.short_desc: Bugzilla version attributes are crazy?

long_desc.thetext:
If I open a mylar bug, if presents me with a "1.0" value on "version" attribute combo. But if I try to submit, the server says that it is not a legal value. If I submit, and go to the web interface, I can see that there is no "1.0" value available, only 0.9.
The same thing happened today while trying to open a bug on "Target Management" product: it presents me a "1.0.1" value, but on web interface there is only "1.0".
I wonder if there is some mylar bug, or the Eclipse.org server are going crazy?

I just opened a bug using "1.0" version from bug editor. I wonder if this is somewhat related on eclipse.org bugzilla load-balance, because sometimes the web interface does not presents the "diff" option for attachments... Perhaps there is some stale bugzilla...
I'm going to assume this was related to replication/load balancing server side. Should this re-occur lets re-open.

bug.short_desc: Refactor conversion of objects into Mylar internal structures to use adapters

long_desc.thetext:
Fork from bug#165088 comment#54:
There are many places inside source code where a selection is tested against many ifs to extract a common interface.
Make them all adapters would simplify the code and make it more extensible, e.g., third-parties can expose a adapter for a proprietary object to some Mylar structure and get integrated "automagically".

We'll also have to provide adapter factory for platform objects, such as Project, Resource, etc...
It also seems like description is over generalized. Currently the most important use case is the actions on some arbitrary selection (elements in the Task List, nodes in Package Explorer, etc).

bug.short_desc: [EditorMgmt] Investigate possible editor tab management improvements

long_desc.thetext:
Created an attachment (id=55888) wide vertical tab in editor
agree. how about these ideas: vertical tabs (can fit more items, with more of the filename) stack editor position according to grouped view hide extension (icon is already there)

Created an attachment (id=55889) wide vertical tab in editor
agree. how about these ideas: vertical tabs (can fit more items, with more of the filename) stack editor position according to grouped view hide extension (icon is already there)

how about moving the toolbar icons in the editor tab?
- brings the toolbar buttons closer to the actual area of use. - solves the problem of "jumping" from 1 to 2 rows of toolbars when users move between tabs.

Andre, thanks for your comments! For now, all I did was experiment with a new scheme for managing the tabs. Time permitting, I would like to see if moving the editor toolbar items to the editor area is doable, I like this idea too.
About what I did so far - it's not perfect, but I already like it a lot because it is much more predictable than before. Here is how it works:
- No MRU visibility for tabs - you see a "sliding window" of all your tabs. - Opening an editor either replaces the editor in the current tab, or opens a new tab. A new tab is opened when the current editor is pinned. - Editors are pinned automatically when they first become dirty. Saving does not make them un-pinned. - You can open a new empty tab (File->New Editor Tab).
What you get is very similar to tabbed browsing in e.g. Firefox as long as you don't start editing files. Any opening of editors, or navigating between editors (e.g. F3, clicking on links) will take place in the same tab, and you only get a new tab when you create one using File->New Editor Tab. (I have bound this to Ctrl-T...)
It differs from Firefox behaviour when you start editing a file. From now on, this file will stay in that tab until you close it, or un-pin it. The intuition is that files you are editing (or have edited) are more important than the others where you were just browsing and should stay around.
Overall, this scheme leads to a smaller number of tabs being opened, depending on how much you browse vs. how much you edit. It also makes it predictable where editors will open because it's either in the current tab or in a new tab. You can leave a tab open as a reminder to do something in that file, or because you want to continue browsing in there - if it is not the current tab, it will stay around.
If anyone would like to experiment with this, you need the last N-build from this year (N20061220-0010 - watch out for bug 168700 if you are on Linux) and change two preferences: - General->Search, uncheck "reuse editors" - General->Appearance, pick the "3.3 presentation (experimental)" If you were using the 3.3 presentation already, you need to switch to the default and then back to 3.3 again.
Here are the next steps for this: - The navigation history (back and forward buttons in the toolbar) should be tab-specific, not global, just like in Firefox - Window->New Editor should clone the current tab including its navigation history and needs to be renamed accordingly - Navigating to a file that is already showing in another tab should not switch to that tab, what you want is this file in the current tab. Browsers don't switch tabs just because you navigated to a page you already have open in another tab.

Hey Boris, thanks for looking into this stuff, I'm glad to see that tabbed browsing for Eclipse is still evolving.
With respect to pinning and replacing existing editors- that idea kind of scares me, to be honest ;) let me explain. First, would newly opened documents be pinned by default, or not? Maybe a good default is unpinned when you open it, but as soon as the file becomes dirty [you show an active interest in editing the document], it becomes pinned. If it's pinned by default, then you must actively unpin it to say that you're ok with it being closed, which is like saying "I probably want to close this document but I don't want to commit to closing this document". If you don't mind if it's closed, wouldn't you just close it now and save yourself the screenspace? I think that'd be pretty likely. If it's *unpinned* by default, it might become a mental chore to have to remember to click a button just to make sure that something you have opened doesn't disappear. I have a large number of projects, each with a large number of source files, so when I accidentally close a document it does take a while (and some mental effort and frustration) to find it again. (Is there a feature request already for CTRL+SHIFT+TAB opens last closed document? I will gladly vote for that.) If I had to remember to pin a document every time I want to keep it open, I might get a little frustrated after a little while (after which I guess I could just revert to turning off "reuse editors", so not TOO big of a deal).
Again, I'd say that maybe the best default behavior is unpinned until the file becomes dirty. If a nightly build was available on the download page, I would test this out right now just to see what it's like at the moment, but getting eclipse from source is more than i want to do right now. ;) but after the holidays, i will try it out.
As far as reusing editors goes, there seems to already be that functionality at the moment, when debugging. If I double-click on a stack frame to go to that line of code in an editor, and then double-click on a different stack frame, the new document replaces the old document. I got burned by this just the other day, where I couldn't look at two files simultaneously unless I opened one of them manually (which was frustrating because I had to find the file, it was in a plugin jar, and i wasn't sure which jar it was in)... I was thinking "I really wish you could pin documents in Eclipse!", so I'm glad you're talking about it now. If you're going to support reusing editors as an option, does this affect files opened during debugging as mentioned? If files that are opened for debugging will reuse windows even if "reuse windows" is not checked in the options, please add the capability to pin these documents anyway.

(In reply to comment #5) > Again, I'd say that maybe the best default behavior is unpinned until the file > becomes dirty. If a nightly build was available on the download page, I would > test this out right now just to see what it's like at the moment, but getting > eclipse from source is more than i want to do right now. ;) but after the > holidays, i will try it out.
Thanks for your comments, yes indeed editors start off unpinned and are automatically pinned when they first become dirty.
I would encourage anyone to try it out before commenting - download the nightly build mentioned in comment #4, and if you are running on Linux, replace the SWT plug-ins with the versions from a recent integration build. (I haven't tested this, but would expect it to work.)

(In reply to comment #6) > I would encourage anyone to try it out before commenting - download the nightly > build mentioned in comment #4, and if you are running on Linux, replace the SWT > plug-ins with the versions from a recent integration build. (I haven't tested > this, but would expect it to work.) >

I am sorry for whetting your appetite but not having a build available right now to try it out.
Happy holidays, Boris

> - Navigating to a file that is already showing in another tab should not > switch to that tab, what you want is this file in the current tab.
Released to HEAD >20070102.
Just FYI - it seems that the last nightly builds are now available on eclipse.org.

A feature I use very often in Firefox is "Open Link in New Window" (Ctrl+Click). This should also be possible in Eclipse when Ctrl+Click and F3 are changed to open in the current tab, e.g. - everywhere via Ctrl+Shift+F3 and - in the editor via Ctrl+Shift+Click.

The approach looks promising, but the broken navigation history makes the 3.3 presentation unusable for me in N20070103-0010:
- open java.lang.Integer - select toString() in Outline - Ctrl+Click "valueOf" in body of toString()
- Alt+Left => expected: caret on invocation of valueOf in Integer => was: caret on line 2 of Integer
- Alt+Right => expected: caret on declaration of String#valueOf(int) => was: caret on line 2 of String

Except for the auto-pinning when dirtied the first time, it looks almost the same as using the old presentation with: [x] Close editors automatically Number of closed editors before reusing: 1 (x) Open new editor ==> please add the option to auto-pin when dirtied - I like it NOTE: this approach does not show the defects mentioned below
I think it would be good enough to add the auto-pin ability to the Editors preference page. Maybe the new presentation could then set those preferences in order to get the desired behavior. This would be transparent for the user and he could later change the 'Editors' settings even when using the new presentation. In addition we could extend some commands (e.g. F3/Ctrl+Click) that allow to open a new editor either in a new or in the current editor part.
Here some detailed findings: - I don't like that the new opening/navigation strategy is tied into the new presentation. I might like the new presentation BUT also like the good old navigation story.
- I find it pretty weird that the 'Editors' preference page changes according to the chosen presentation. See also previous item.
- navigation (F3 & Ctrl+Click) inside same non-pinned editor must not reload the file. Currently it flickers like hell (scrollbar, rulers, etc.).
- navigation (F3 & Ctrl+Click) inside same pinned editor must not open a second instance.
>A feature I use very often in Firefox is "Open Link in New Window" >(Ctrl+Click). This should also be possible in Eclipse when Ctrl+Click and F3 >are changed to open in the current tab, e.g. This might be hard to address with a general solution (modifier) and many different actions might be affected, e.g. also 'Open Type', some quick assist/fixes etc.

Agree that once the right pre-page history support goes in, we will really be able to get a feel for it. But I'll say that I've already grown accustomed to it and much prefer it as a work model. I downloaded 3.2.1 for a home project the other day and was and when faced with the old MRU confusion thought, "Oh right, this :( ".
A sign that the new method is working is that I've started making use of tab position since I can pin and rearrange and they will stay put. My memory is highly spacially oriented so this works great for me.
As for use of Presentation and being able to turn things on/off ala carte, my vote is that we leave it in the Presentation since its a look & feel change (i.e. its the "new eclipse" way of working). Adding more options to the preferences is confusing especially for new users.
Andree, with respect to editor local toolbar usage, we've discussed that independently to this tab management. There seems to be interest in looking into this. Personally I am pro because it moves the tools closer to where the user is working, always a bonus, and because current toolbar is a mess with tools coming and going mysteriously (this way context becomes more explicit).

Re: #14, I don't know if the solution is local editor toolbars, but having Eclipse always jump from 1 to two rows as I click on different kinds of files is very disturbing visually and it slows me down because of the refresh and the 'what the... oh yeah' moments. I keep trying to adjust my window width or disable some toolbars to make it stop but then I'll install something new (say a new plug-in that adds a toolbar button) or hit a new type of file, and it destabilizes the whole thing again.
Just brainstorming but maybe the toolbar buttons should be chevron'd or mru'd too.
A few editors like Compare already have local editor toolbars.

(In reply to comment #15)
Yup, agree about the usability problems Ed.
IMHO, the current approach of a global toolbar is antiquated and full of usability problems. The trend in applications (and for good reason) is to reduce the number of global tools to a minimum, just look at IE 7 as an example. The fact that the toolbar grows and shrinks is indeed distracting and greatly impacts any positional memory people may have. Bring the tools to where you need them. That said, there's always the problem of existing API compatibility to look at...

re comment 14: I can live if the open strategy remains coupled with the new presentation but I see no reason why to hide some preferences in the new mode and why not to allow others to just use the new open strategy by offering that new check box.

I don't know why is it so hard to provide the user with the capability to choose for himself what he likes the best. "Appearance" already provides the capability to choose presentations, why not adding to it? For example, I would recommend adding the skin provided by "http://andrei.gmxhome.de/skins/index.html" which I think is much nicer then even to the new experimental presentation in 3.3 M4. Also, why dont you add an Intellij-like presentation (aka dynamic multiple rows of tabs). If people like the old MRU, leave it in as a selectable presentation. Personally, my greatest complain about Eclipse is that stupid MRU. I keep loosing my file spatial positions and I hate it. It is costing me lots of time to keep searching for the stupid files that keep moving on me. Pinning is of not much use, as I would want to pin all my files so that they keep the position I assigned them. New files should be added at the end of my list waiting for me to assign them a position. I bought a new 24 inch monitor that I run on higher resolution to have more real estate and my file tabs are still confined to a single row. Sounds to me that this MRU issue has not moved much for so long because there is a control freak somewhere that insists for his way. Politic is always a bitch. The weight of the arguments that you must keep backward look and feel or that newcomers would be confused is insignificant when compared against the pain caused by the inadequate implementation forced in everyone throat. Pierre G.

I think you've misinterpreted why MRU has been around as long as it has. Essentially, there's only so many times we can keep changing around how people work. You know, we only have a few shots at getting anything right. Thus we need to chose them carefully based on community feedback and our own reflections on having used it. When we miss, we can't just react, otherwise the entire UI experience thrashes from one extreme to the other.
That said, if you were to start a support group for people driven crazy by MRU then I'd be one of the first to join.
Multiple rows of tabs have been discussed but it didn't gain much popularity. I am sure you will find bugs on it.
I'd like if you could give pinning a try. I wasn't sure about it but now that I've started using it, it seems to address the issue. In web browsing, I don't need pinning because I can explicitly say "open this link in a new tab". We can't do that in Eclipse because there's too many ways of generating new editors (e.g. search). Thus pinning as an explicit way of keeping content from moving. Mind you, many times I've filled out web forms, been halfway through and lost the content because a link opened in the same tab and my entered information wasn't preserved - "pin on modification" would be nice there too.
In web browsing there is a combination of tab reuse and tab preservation, and it is this that we've been trying to learn from.
You bring up explicitly rearranging tabs. Perhaps moving a tab should pin it, since the implication is that you care about its contents (cared enough to move it). Worth some consideration although always there's a concern around doing too much automatically which doesn't fit user's intent.
Finally, with respect to preferences, we have too many and its near impossible for any but our power users to manage. Thus our general approach is to introduce new look and feel as one hopefully cohesive package.

> Thus our general approach is to >introduce new look and feel as one hopefully cohesive package. As previously stated I don't like that all or nothing approach and I don't think one additional preference (auto-pin) to give users who want to stay with the current editor tabs would be a problem, especially because that page already talks about pinning and dirty editors.

(In reply to comment #20) > I don't > think one additional preference (auto-pin) to give users who want to stay with > the current editor tabs would be a problem
The new behaviour is more than just auto-pinning: it removes the MRU visibility behaviour for tabs, it only replaces the currently active tab as opposed to any non-dirty and unpinned one, it always shows tabs (no unibrow), and it changes the history to work per tab.
I am not keen on exposing all of this as individual preferences.
I agree, me neither. What I meant is that the auto-pin would be a good addition for those that want to keep the old way.
*** Bug 50116 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

(In reply to comment #23) > *** Bug 50116 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Found an old bug that proposed almost exactly what we are implementing now. :)

(In reply to comment #19) > I think you've misinterpreted why MRU has been around as long as it has.
I am sorry for my misinterpretation. In general, I find Eclipse to be a fantastic tool and much superior to many others. You guys are definitely doing a fantastic job. I agree with the "not jumping boats just because" statement. However, I have been a user of Borland and Microsoft tools (just to name a few) for a very long time and each tool has their quirks and weak points but for some reason, tab positioning never was an issue for me prior to my MRU encounter. The level of frustration I experience with it does decrease despite my effort to be understanding. Have you looked at the Extended VS Presentation I mentioned? I have played with multiple rows of tab in Intellij and find it just fine. The idea of reusing one tab while browsing through code is good but I don't see why it could not be done in an editor opened for that purpose at the end of the list (again Extended VS). Perhaps the user should be given the option to choose which file to close when it is needed. I simply cannot get used to the tab reordering done on me, and it seams that many feel the same so in a sense, I am speaking on their behalf as well. I have tried the pinning but it still seams to reorders tabs on me and managing pinning is just an extra burden. Given that perfection does not exist, then in my opinion, providing one presentation with multiple rows, one similar to the Extended VS and the MRU for the masochist would seams to be a good compromise.

i finally had a chance to try this out. i notice at the moment that you need to right-click on the editor to pin it. i hope you're planning on adding a button on the editor, hopefully next to the 'x' close button on each tab?
i also notice that if you select two files in package explorer, right-click and say "open", only the last file in the selection appears. when you select multiple files and open them, it's reasonable to suspect that the user wants them all open.
also, when i applied the settings, eclipse asked me to restart, but it died on my machine- i had to start it up again manually. i've got a winxp machine running java 1.5.06.

Pierre,
our proposal removes the MRU behaviour, as described in Comment #4:
> ... > it is much more predictable than before. Here is how it works: > > - No MRU visibility for tabs - you see a "sliding window" of all your tabs. > ...
Also, if you would like to try out the new behaviour, see comment #4 for how to enable it.

(In reply to comment #26) > also, when i applied the settings, eclipse asked me to restart, but it died on > my machine- i had to start it up again manually. i've got a winxp machine > running java 1.5.06. That was bug 169539 (fixed in next I-build).

I love the notion that the editor panel is a browser window and should behave like one, with tab management options!
Has anyone thought of tab groups and tab colouring? See http://piro.sakura.ne.jp/xul/tabextensions/index.html.en#screenshots for some great ideas.

(In reply to comment #29) > I love the notion that the editor panel is a browser window and should behave > like one, with tab management options!
