Very cool. Some comments (which might already be mirrored above):
Working Sets ------------
I love the new Top Level Elements > Working Sets option to allow me to see all my sets and navigate through them all. However, I notice it won't show me all of them, which I'm guessing is a bug. I'll attach screenshots if people are curious (or open a new bug if you'd prefer). In a nutshell, I did this:
DownTriangleMenu > Deselect Working Set DownTriangleMenu > Top Level Elements > Working Sets DownTriangleMenu > Configure Working Sets... > Select All 8 working sets are shown in the Package Explorer, plus "Other Projects" set
DownTriangleMenu > Top Level Elements > Projects DownTriangleMenu > Select Working Set... 9 working sets are shown in the dialog
I also notice this behaviour doesn't work in the Navigator, where it ought to as well.
Autopin -------
I'm not sure if I like this yet, but the idea that if I'm looking for a file to edit (clicking on files in the Pack Expl or Nav) or going through a search checking which ones to edit I only have one tab open until I actually edit a file and thus pin it is pretty cool.
However, I think the threshhold for 'this is one to keep' should be set lower -- such as clicking in the editor, selecting text, or any other interaction. If I don't touch the editor, fine, make it go away. If I *do* touch it, pin it. Or maybe just open the next file in a new tab.
If you're going to use this reuse metaphor, you need a way to force a file to open in a new tab, like CTRL-click for "open in new tab" vs. "open in current tab."
GrabFocus ---------
Haven't seen this yet. How do I test it out?
Overall, this kicks ass. After Alblue's comment the other day about Working Sets I was all fired up to blog about how cool they are (missing button notwithstanding). If you don't mind, I'd like to blog about this as well.

Thanks for your feedback, and feel free to blog about it! GrabFocus (should rather be called NoGrabFocus) doesn't work well with the editor tab tweaklet, but if you install it, views or editors that are opened programmatically will not come to the front and "steal" your keyboard focus. See bug 85608 for more information.
As for auto-pinning an editor just by clicking in it, I don't agree - most of the time I am just browsing code and following references (Ctrl-click, or F3). When I am in this mode, I do click in the editor area and/or make selections, but I'm happy to just have one tab as my browsing context, just like in a web browser. If you just want to keep the current editor contents, for example to keep the current browsing context with its tab-specific history, the tweaklet contains a command called "New Editor Tab". I changed the key bindings as follows to make it similar to the web browser behaviour:
Command Default Binding My Personal Binding New Editor Tab - Ctrl-T Quick Hierarchy Ctrl-T Ctrl-H Search Dialog Ctrl-H -
And yes, we need a way to open a new editor tab when double-clicking on a file, or following a link. Unfortunately, Ctrl-click is already taken. Let me know if you have an idea for solving this.

(In reply to comment #35) > not come to the front and "steal" your keyboard focus. See bug 85608 for
Can't say that's ever been a problem. Making Update Manager not pop to the foreground (bug 189523) while I'm typing would be nice, but that's a dialog, not an editor. The only view that ever does that for me is the PDE Error Log but I usually have that one closed anyway so it can't annoy me, and only open it if I need it (which is rare).
> As for auto-pinning an editor just by clicking in it, I don't agree - most of > the time I am just browsing code and following references (Ctrl-click, or F3). > When I am in this mode, I do click in the editor area and/or make selections, > but I'm happy to just have one tab as my browsing context, just like in a web > browser.
Yes, for browsing java code with JDT, that would be ideal. For html/php/xml/properties/shell and other releng stuff, it's not so useful. Could the behaviour have a properties option for something like:
[x] Click in editor to autopin tabs
If you're browsing files in the Pack Expl or Navigator, rather than CTRL-clicking your way from .java to .class to .class, then click-in-editor-to-pin action would work, but only if you have that behaviour enabled.
> If you just want to keep the current editor contents, for example to > keep the current browsing context with its tab-specific history, the tweaklet > contains a command called "New Editor Tab". I changed the key bindings as > follows to make it similar to the web browser behaviour:
Does ALT-forward-arrow and ALT-back-arrow move thru a tab's history while on a tab / in an editor?
> open a new editor tab when double-clicking on a file, > or following a link. Unfortunately, Ctrl-click is already taken.
How about ALT-click, SHIFT-click or CTRL-ALT-click?
Or, if you're keyboarding around, SHIFT-ALT-T? You could have a whole tab-related set of multikey commands like the SHIFT-ALT-Q and SHIFT-ALT-X keybindings.
In Konqueror/Firefox, you can right-click a link and "open in new tab / open in this tab." To do that in JDT could mean...
Hold down ALT (or CTRL-ALT?) to do the same as CTRL now does, but with a different colour underline or maybe a hover icon, like an asterisk (ie., for "new"), and target a new tab instead of the current one?
If you like SHIFT-ALT-T as a key mapping menu, why not something like these:
SHIFT-ALT-T,P Pin/unpin this &This Tab SHIFT-ALT-T,T Open Link in &This Tab SHIFT-ALT-T,N Open Link in &New Tab SHIFT-ALT-T,R Open Link in &Right (Next) Tab SHIFT-ALT-T,L Open Link in &Left (Previous) Tab SHIFT-ALT-T,G &Group This Tab [start a group (pick a new tab colour)] SHIFT-ALT-T,H End T&his Tab Group [end current group] SHIFT-ALT-T,U &Ungroup This Tab [drop current tab from whatever group it's in and revert it to uncoloured]
Of course the only problem with SHIFT-ALT-T is you can't do it one-handed... so what about SHIFT-ALT-A (as in, All about tabs) or SHIFT-ALT-Z (Ze tabs! Ze tabs!) instead? ;-)

> And yes, we need a way to open a new editor tab when double-clicking on a file, > or following a link. Unfortunately, Ctrl-click is already taken. Let me know > if you have an idea for solving this.
Using the middle mouse button (often the scroll wheel one) is also a common way to open a link in a different tab. It has its usability issues but works one-handed. Not sure how well it works for double-clicks though.

(In reply to comment #36) > Does ALT-forward-arrow and ALT-back-arrow move thru a tab's history while on a > tab / in an editor?
Yes.

(In reply to comment #34) > [..] Working Sets [..]
I don't see how this is related to tab management. I also can't reproduce any problems with Java and Resource working sets in I20070608-1718. Please file a bug for JDT/UI if you have steps to reproduce this in the Package Explorer.

(In reply to comment #36) > Yes, for browsing java code with JDT, that would be ideal. For > html/php/xml/properties/shell and other releng stuff, it's not so useful. Could > the behaviour have a properties option for something like: > > [x] Click in editor to autopin tabs
The problem with making this a preference is that people do many different kinds of task in a single Eclipse install. For example, someone could be doing both java things and releng things which would require changing the preference when switching tasks.

(In reply to comment #39) > > [..] Working Sets [..] > bug for JDT/UI if you have steps to reproduce this in the Package Explorer.
Cannot reproduce except in my own workspace. Very odd. Ah, well.
What does the Working Set tweaklet do? Seems everything I've seen seems to be in fact part of the JDT UI (Package Explorer vs. Project Explorer, bug 192931), not the tweaklet. How can I see/test the tweaklet's new function?
(In reply to comment #40) > > [x] Click in editor to autopin tabs > The problem with making this a preference is that people do many different > kinds of task in a single Eclipse install. For example, someone could be doing > both java things and releng things which would require changing the preference > when switching tasks.
Agreed, and I'm one of those polyglot types that has to wear a lot of hats in a given day. ;-) I guess then it's better to have a unique keybinding for this, like CTRL-click to reuse current tab but ALT-click to open in a new tab.

I just want to "vote" for an UltraEdit-like stacked tabs presentation. This is one of the main reasons (if not THE main reason) I continue to pay for UltraEdit in preference to other free editors. It's also a great editor, but the stacked tabs are awesome.
My argument is simple. In any production environment I find code bodies are large. I often find myself with 20-30 or more files open at once. Scrolling back and forth in such a situation is awful. I just want to see all of the tabs and I want them readable. Stacked tabs is the only way I've seen this work well.
Download an evaluation copy of UltraEdit and look at how it works. When the tab bar fills up you get the left/right scrolling behavior. If you then pull the tab bar lower edge down it opens up with more rows and the scrolling behavior goes away until you fill it up again.
This seems like the best of both worlds. You get the scrolling behavior that many people seem to like and the stacked row behavior that a few malcontents such as myself want. You just lose the MRU re-ordering behavior.
Too bad.
Just want to add my vote for I just want to "vote" for an UltraEdit-like stacked tabs presentation.

bug.short_desc: Non-exists svg image isn't processed as the normal image.[0001]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Non-exists svg image isn't processed as the normal image.
Build number:2.2.0.v20061216
Steps to reproduce: 1. Copy a svg image to resource folder. 2. New a report, insert an image and select the svg file, set alt-text as "not found". 3. Delete the svg file and preview the report in IE and Firefox.
Expected result: Because the svg image doesn't exist, so alt-text should display
Actual result: In IE, I saw a gray background, right click will see svg context menu. In Firefox, I saw error message as:org.eclipse.birt.report.service.api.ReportServiceException: Missing image file.
Error log:N/A

If there is an exception in get the image, the viewer shouldn't write the exception into the output stream.
It should return 404 NOT FOUND.
If throws exception when get image, dont write exception into output stream.

Verify in build 2.2.0.v20061225.
At present, both in IE and Firefox will not throw any exception. Firefox will display a blank area. IE will display a gray svg image.

bug.short_desc: [Regression] Nothing is memorized when focus is in other text field [0001]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Nothing is memorized when focus is in other text field. Regression of bug #148168
Build number: 2.1.2.v20061215-0710

bug.short_desc: Variability was not removed correctly in case of a transferred dependency

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.2.0
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create plugins p1, p2, p3, make p1 referenced by p2, and p2 referenced by p3 2. Create one type of element in both p3 and p1, e.g. discipline1 in p1, discipline3 in p3 (because of p1 referenced by p3 via p2, thus p3 can 'see' p1) 3. make discipline3 contribute to dicipline1. (That can be completed with no error.) 4. Unset all references between the plugins, then p2 was not referenced by p3, yet p2 was not referenced by p1. Problem:--> the Variability on dicipline3 was not prompted to remove. (now even the each plugin are standalone, but the Variability was kept) expect result: 1. Ref move dialog 2. Variability was removed
More information: 1. Not a regression. 2. when deleting p2 and p1, the reference will be detected, and prompt to confirm the removal from p3, that's right. 3. Any type of reference(variabilitys or associations) acrossing plugins, using this kind of 'transferred dependency', may contains this kind of problem.

Created an attachment (id=62727) Patch for this fix
Patch has been applied on 04/02/2007 2.55 PM PST. Please verify this defect on appropriate build.
Thanks, Lokanath Jagga
patch applied and fixed the problem.

Verified on Efp1.2, 20070402-1915. Partly fixed.
assume: p3 reference to p2, and p2 reference to p1, then set discipline3 have a variability to discipline1. And,
A). cut the relation between (p3,p2) B). cut the relation between (p2,p1)
both way can make p3 to lose relation to p1.
Now, the fix has resolve the problem in the senario A (the variability between tow disciplines was removed), however, senario B still holds same kind of problem.
Thank, By zhaohui.
please investigate the case b.

All the dependency cases have been taken care. Tested Case A and Case B and both are working as designed.
Patch has been applied on 04/16/07, 11.30 AM PST.
Thanks, ~Lokanath Jagga
Fix is verified on epf1.2, 20070413-1705

You can't pass multibyte parameter in URL directly. Please use java.net.URLEncoder.encode(param, "utf-8") to encode the parameter value, then pass it by URL.
Please try it again.

It OK Jerry, I must to send <%=java.net.URLEncoder.encode(param, "utf-8")%> in my query string. It close for this bug but I have a question to ask you again. When birt-viewer export data to csv, the column's data and column's name is come from a sql query statment not from a design column in report.rptdesign, then some column that calculate in report.rptdesign(column that not come from sql query statment) can not show in csv. Current, export data can export all the columns included computed columns in DataSet design, not only from sql statement. Please check it.

Thanks Jerry, birt can export it but I want to advice you about this 1. When use 'AS' to make new name of column in sql birt show original column name and new 'AS' name in birt-viewer csv select column 2. In birt-viewer csv select datasorce, I think birt should show name of datasource that set in report.rptdesign not from sql object as 'element_5' 3. I don't sure this is a bug. When I set page break of sequence row result set birt can show correct but if I set page break for row of result set that have group-by column birh generate and show wrong when row of result set = row of page break in group-by row. Thanks again for your support. Good luck Jerry.

bug.short_desc: Register service with an invalid server, validation not done at the registration level.

long_desc.thetext: While registering the service with an invalid server is accepted but throwing error when using the event emitter client. Instead it can be validated during registration.

Tim , seems this can happen right, because we can deploy for a server which is going to come up shortely in a paused state. And later when the server is up and running we can change the status. Do you think that would be valid?

For now we should just handle the error gracefully. A server being unavailable should be reported to the user with meaningful error message.
In the future we will add a server view which can show/check the current status of the server by
Tim, Viji is talking about the Service Flow registration "endointURL". While registring the Service Flow plugin will validate whether the service is available.
A meaningful error is being responded if the URL is not of a specific format, service cannot be reached currently.
a meaningful message is now reported to the user

bug.short_desc: java.io locking not working on linux

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.3M4
Steps To Reproduce: 1. ./eclipse -data /tmp/x -vmargs -Dosgi.locking=java.io 2. ./eclipse -data /tmp/x -vmargs -Dosgi.locking=java.io
More information: java.io locking does not work on linux. I can confirm that the some thing works on windows. Looks like the filesystem on linux (ext3) will allow the deletion of a file that has a java rw lock on it.
what VM? Seems like it is a VM issue since the same code is run on Windows as on Linux.

I disagree, the problem IMHO is a filesystem/OS issue, not a VM issue. For verification purposes I tried to open the same workspace twice with: Sun's JRE 1.5.0_06 and IBM's J9 VM (build 2.3, J2RE 1.5.0 IBM J9 2.3 Linux x86-32 j9vmxi3223-20060504 (JIT enabled) on linux: same thing with both tests, the workspace was opened twice.

Is there a reason you are using java.io locking instead of java.nio locking? Is it because you use an NFS mounted drive for the configuration area (bug 44735)? or is there some other reason java.nio locking will not work for you?

Ciao Guys :) java.io locking is supposed to be a workaround for those cases where java.nio does not work (NFS filesystems etc.). This workaround is entirely broken on linux, worsening the original problem a customer has ... Ciao, hh

See bug 96034
This is true, java.io locking does not work at all on Linux and possibly other Unix style file systems. The reason is you can delete a file on linux which another process or thread has open for write.
The only way I can see how to fix this is to change the strategy java.io locking uses. Instead of attempting to delete the lock file as a check it could determine the Location is locked if the lock file exists. But this strategy has proven faulty in the past because a Location is left locked on a VM crash. This is because we have no chance to delete the lock file on a crash.
Any ideas on how to fix java.io locking? Or would it be more worth our while to figure out why java.nio locking does not work in some situations?
Any update on this one?
Can the fix for bug 59780 adress this one too?

(In reply to comment #7) > Can the fix for bug 59780 adress this one too? >
unfortunately, no

bug.short_desc: Generated editors should use paletteProvider extension

long_desc.thetext:
Generated editors contribute their palette programatically instead of using the paletteProvider extension. It would be better to generate code that uses the paletteProvider extension as this would allow the palette to be contributed to other editors easily.
This bug was marked as fixed on 2006-02-15 13:09:59. See Bug 126199 <https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=126199>

Idea was to generate palette content + use palette provider for the extensibility (generated createPaletteRoot first calls super.createPaletteRoot() to examine all registered providers)
For another editor you can: 1. Create own palette description (referencing the same .gmftool model elements) and generate it once more - it's simple 2. Manually write palette provider for the second editor calling ???PaletteFactory().fillPalette() generated for first editor and register it. 3. Directly call ??PaletteFactory().fillPalette() generated for first editor from the second editor's createPaletteRoot() method (requires modification of generated code).
I think one of these three methods should be suitable for your situation and all of them are quite easy. Please correct me if Im wrong or close this request.

(In reply to comment #1) > Idea was to generate palette content + use palette provider for the > extensibility (generated createPaletteRoot first calls > super.createPaletteRoot() to examine all registered providers)
But a generated editor A can not contribute to the palette of another editor (generated or not) this way because generated editor A does not provide paletteProviders extension point.
> > For another editor you can: > 1. Create own palette description (referencing the same .gmftool model > elements) and generate it once more - it's simple
I want to generate an editor B to act as an "extension" to another (generated) editor A. Because I not only want to reuse the tooling definition but also (part of) the generated (and manually modified) code of A this does not fulfill my needs.
> 2. Manually write palette provider for the second editor calling > ???PaletteFactory().fillPalette() generated for first editor and register it. > 3. Directly call ??PaletteFactory().fillPalette() generated for first editor > from the second editor's createPaletteRoot() method (requires modification of > generated code).
Why not use the (extension) mechanisms already provided by the runtime which eases reuse a lot, I think? In the use case given above I want to be able to reuse edit parts, edit policies, etc. from the existing editor as much as possible. When using a new gmfmap which references the tooling and graph model from editor A I e.g. need to update two editors when doing manual changes on the generated code.
> I think one of these three methods should be suitable for your situation and > all of them are quite easy. Please correct me if Im wrong or close this > request.
I can use on of these to get the palette working the way I want. But in order to make generated editors more flexible with respect to reuse, generation should make use of the extension points provided by the runtime, I think. I can not completely judge if it is possible at the moment to reuse much of editor A in my use case. E.g. look for access restrictions of classes in editor A which prohibits their use (e.g. calling protected methods) in editor B.
So if you do not want to call it a bug I can make it an enhancement request (although it is a blocker for my work ;-))

> But a generated editor A can not contribute to the palette of another editor > (generated or not) this way because generated editor A does not provide > paletteProviders extension point.
If editor A contributes palette provider chances are that there is an editor B that don't want to have this contribution. It's possible to limit palette contribution applicability to particular editor that this makes it effectively unreusable. So the policy is to contribute nothing so you could precisely control what you reuse and where and not to interfere with other editors.
I guess that we could add option to gmfgen model to specify whether we should generate palette provider, thoughts?

(In reply to comment #2):
>I want to generate an editor B to act as an "extension" to another (generated) >editor A. Because I not only want to reuse the tooling definition but also >(part of) the generated (and manually modified) code of A this does not >fulfill my needs. Well, I think corresponding support from the side of tooling will help you a lot in this case (I mean if tolling provide a possibility for editor B to extend editor A on a level of GMF diagram definitions - *models). This is interesting use case and I hope we will support it in future.
>Why not use the (extension) mechanisms already provided by the runtime which >eases reuse a lot, I think? In the use case given above I want to be able to We are trying to use extension mechanisms only in the situations then we really need extensions. You should know that usage of extensions introduces a number of disadvantages in addition to the known flexibility, so we are trying to "keep balance" ;-) And in an ideal situation I hope tooling will be able to generate all this "interconnecting code" for editors A and B to work as a solid structure and reuse corresponding common .java parts.
>I can use on of these to get the palette working the way I want. Actually I suggest you to use 2. or 3. If editor B will extends editor A then plugin with editor B will have a dependencies to the plugin with editor A, so you can modify createPaletteRoot() of generated editor B and call APaletteFactory().fillPalette() from java. I think it's even easier then modifying plugin.xml and registering corresponding palette provider for editor B there. ;-)
>E.g. look for access restrictions of classes in editor A which >prohibits their use (e.g. calling protected methods) in editor B. Unfortunately I never tried to extend one editor with another one, so I appreciate if you file corresponding requests. I think these requests will be very useful for pointing out which parts of the generated editor could be reused by another one and to force tooling to support this kind of extensibility on model level.
>So if you do not want to call it a bug I can make it an enhancement request >(although it is a blocker for my work ;-)) I don't care about the naming - I'd like to gather information from you and push GMF to generate as much as it possible. ;-)
I hope, that for the current state you can modify the code (since you are modifying it in any case ;-)) and for future I'd like to see GMF generating even more for you and this is why I'm asking you to submit additional requests for tooling extensibility.

1. I doubt it's common usecase to reuse generated palette in some other editor. Once you need this, you can either use code directly invoking appropriate factory or (in case your usecase is inherently dynamic, which is even more rare) you may need to manually write a provider (10 lines of code, just delegating to the factory. 2. Extensions, with all the power they bring in a controlled environment, easily gets us to a disaster when there are few *not-very-polite* gmf-built tool providers. With palette extensions in the way we had them your editor's palette may eventually get poluuted with all others tools and it will be a nightmare for end users.
This is WONTFIX to me, unless there are opinions the usecase of *dynamic* generated extensions to palette is very common.
Closing, as there seems to be no arguments why xml programming is preferred to java.

bug.short_desc: Edited source file changes not listed in available list on event action map

long_desc.thetext: 1.In the event action map, change URL form the source file and save it. 2.Now edit the service flow from designer tab. 3.The old URL is getting listed in the deselected(available)list but the changed URL is not listed in the available service flow list.

This bug is invalid. In the event map scrren "edit button" is used to select the values from .svc file.The changes made in the source page will not reflect in the "edit button" pop up dialog. you can get the changes in only designer view of .alf file.
you can also see the source(EndpointURL) changes in edit button(now changed as Map Service) pop up dialog
you can also see the source(EndpointURL) changes in edit button(now changed as Map Service) pop up dialog.

bug.short_desc: GNU example templates for CDT Template Engine

long_desc.thetext:
This is an enhancement to support the template engine submission made with bug 160012. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=160012
These example templates will help in understanding the template engine working and also provide basic information on how to create templates for your own projects using template engine. At the same time these GNU templates can be used to create projects that can be used in your C/C++ projects. We have included example projects creation using different design patterns mechanisms as explained in Gang of Four's Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software book.
I hope these example template projects are useful for the GNU CDT users. I have developed the C/C++ code used in these example templates on my own. Please let me know if there are errors/mistakes in the C/C++ code generated using these templates and I will correct them.
Created an attachment (id=55913) GNU Templates Plugin Sources
Created an attachment (id=63030) GNU Example Templates to use with CDT Template Engine
Created an attachment (id=64016) New version of example plugins to reflect changes in core TE plugins
Created an attachment (id=64017) New version of example plugins to reflect changes in core TE plugins
Created an attachment (id=64852) Examples integrated into new CDT Project Wizard Mainpage

Let me target this to the RC0 also and I'll take a look whether this could be included with the gnu tool-chain definitions
Mikhail

(In reply to comment #6) > Let me target this to the RC0 also and I'll take a look whether this could be > included with the gnu tool-chain definitions > Mikhail
That's the plan. Probably not all templates need to be included in there. As Doug already proposed, some simple helloworld templates should be copied into gnu plugins.

I have added a couple of Helloworld templates to gnu.ui plugin, so that this plugin is not needed any more. I don't want to post another patch to the templaet engine submission right now with this change. I will post this patch after the submission.

Yes, I'd like to keep this simple to start so the user isn't overwhelmed by templates. My understanding was that these were just examples. I'm not sure they would get used much by our community. A simple hello world template to get users started would be sufficient for now.

Using Design patterns as templates is counter-productive to learning about Patterns. Especially when problematic patterns such as Singleton (which should be banned) or very naive implementations as for Observer are provided.
C++ provides good abstractions within the language (i.e. templates :-) and "auto-generated" code by a tool that is later hand-modified is IMHO often a very bad substitute for good abstractions.

(In reply to comment #10) > Using Design patterns as templates is counter-productive to learning about > Patterns. Especially when problematic patterns such as Singleton (which should > be banned) or very naive implementations as for Observer are provided. > C++ provides good abstractions within the language (i.e. templates :-) and > "auto-generated" code by a tool that is later hand-modified is IMHO often a > very bad substitute for good abstractions.
Thanks for letting know. My original intention in providing these examples was to show to use template engine and how it makes your job easy for the most complicated project creation process e.g. to create classes for an AbstractFactory pattern. This will not be submitted to CDT. CDT provides a couple of simple hello world examples to show the templates.
For I marked as fixed because it has done the job of providing the samples. At the sametime in future if somebody wants to pick the examples and modify them to suit for theri needs, they can always get the patch attached to this bug.

bug.short_desc: [FastView] Two instances of a view part can be created by minimize/restore

Steps To Reproduce: 1.Minimize the view part 2.Click on the view tray button (not the restore button) 3.The view is displayed as fast view, move it on the page 4.Then restore the view by pressing the restore button next to the view tray button or the view tray button again -> a second instance or pane of the view part is displayed
More information:

The effects of changing the page's view structure while a minimized view is being displayed as a fast view is already being worked on as part of bug 153957.
This is one example but there are others (notably closing the view).

bug.short_desc: The indexer can't distinguish between class definitions and class forward

long_desc.thetext: The indexer can't distinguish between class definitions and class forward declarations. This bug was resolved in (bug# 59493) but has reappeared in CDT3.1.1 release, I assume due to new implementation of the indexer and parser.

I have troubles understanding the problem you are encountering. The index does distinguish between definitions and declarations, use IName.isDefinition() to test the property. If there is specific problem you are encountering, please describe how to reproduce it and reopen the bug.
